Tertiary Education monopoly of major airline To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that: 1. The proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich; Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students. 2. The proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a "poor risk" (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness. 3. In regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans, it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education. 4. The proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early. 5. The proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children. Your petitioners therefore pray that: (i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any earnest consideration to this courses or for any category of students; (ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students. (iii) that- comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced. (iv) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance. (v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalised be rescinded. And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray. by Mrs Child, Mr Humphreys, Mr Les MCMahon and Dr Theophanous. Petitions received. Excise on Beer To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: I. The hotel industry in Australia is long-established and a valuable part of the community of this nation, providing places where the people may partake of the three basic needs of life; a place to eat, a place to drink, a place to sleep. 2. The hotel industry is accepted throughout the nation as occupying an important place in the social and economic activities of Australia. 3. The hotel industry is almost entirely within the private sector and makes a large contribution to the government in taxes of various kinds. . 4. The hotel indust-y has a need to sustain an appropriate level of turnover and growth, to make profit, and to sustain and improve the level of employment. 5. The hotel industry of Australia is gravely concerned at published reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthc?ming Budget. 6. Sales of beer constitute the major source of income of most of the industry's 5,811 hotels in Australia. 7. The very steep riSes in beer excise in 1975 and 1978 severely retarded the growth of the Australian hotel industry. 8. Any further increases in excise on beer iIi the 1981 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly .growing needs of the community. 9. Such is its significance as a community requi'rement, beer occupies a place on the Consumer Price Index, and any alteration to its cost to the community would have an inHationary effect. 10. Any increase in excise would result in and force the hotel industry to pass on such increases to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer. 11. Higher excise would be upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State Licence linked to excise rates. 12. The hotel industry of Australia already is gravely handicapped by heavy excise and other a standstill; and, inevitably must decline if beer excise is incre.ased. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives: (l) Recognise the importance and place of the Australian Hotel industry in the social and economic life of the nation. (2) Accept that the viability of the hotel industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable . continue to provide for the hotel needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism. And further, that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Cunningham, Mr Scott and Mr Thomson. Petitions received. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency: (I) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under "Cosmetics" as at present), in order to the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions. (2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects facture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of products and instructions for usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals tially or actually harmful to users. (3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate. Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures. Privacy and Personal Information To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that: Paragraphs 107 and 108 of the Privacy and Personal Information discussion paper number 14, brought down by the Law Reform Commission in June 1980, undermines the family unit and the authority of parents, which is the Christian basis of our society, by proposing that "between 12 and 16 years, a child should be entitled to object to disclosure of information to a parent." It is your petitioners sincere belief that: (a) an adolescent between the ages of 12 and 16 is not at a mature enough stage the disclosure of information to a parent will be in the best interests of the adolescent. (b) as a record keeper has and as his moral standards a parent, he should not be permitted to come between child and parent. (c) a parent has a unique position which may enable him/her to perceive a situation that the record keeper does not. The parent must therefore be aware of the problem if remedial action is to be taken, and has the right to guide the child in the direction he/she feels fit. Your petitioners therefore pray: That the Members of the House of Representatives will reject the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission and find some other means to protect children from the excessive abuse of some parents. Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: FOREIGN CAPITAL
text: I refer the Treasurer to the extraordinary level of volatile portfolio investment or so called hot money, exceeding some $2,OOOm which flowed into Australia last year and which was largely directed towards speculation in real estate, shares and the takeover of Australian Notice of Motion industry. Does the Treasurer recognise the disruptive effects of these short term capital movements which aggravate inflation and force up interest rates? Rather than penalising Australian homebuyers, consumers and manufacturing and farm industries with the cost of more inflation and crippling interest rates, will the Treasurer imthan as mediately impose controls on short term foreign capital inflows?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: FOREIGN CAPITAL
text: The Government is naturally watching developments on Australia's. external account very closely. It is necessary, in responding to the present situation, to adopt an appropriate mixture of policies and not to rely overheavily on CONTROL one particular response. The examination that I have had carried out and the up-to-date advice Notice of Motion which is available to me does not indicate that speculation in real estate constitutes an undue element of the volume of private capital inflow that has come into this country in recent months. The honourable gentleman knows as well as other honourable members that it has been an opjective which arise from the associinstallations with of this Government-the objective has attracted a degree of bipartisan support on occasions around Australia-to establish a state of affairs in which this country is seen as a reliable and attractive country in which to invest, and is able to maximise the benefits of overseas investment whilst at the saine time ensuring that the appropriate opportunities are provided for Australians to share in on strategic and regional arms the resource development of Australia. . The responses to large private capital inflow are a number. It is currently not the intention of the Government to introduce the capital controls Notice of Motion of the type mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition. It would, of course, bea very foolish person who totally ruled out particular responses in this area. I say to the honourable gentleman, as I have said on a number of occasions in the past,that earlier when these controls were introduced they were arbitrary and inefficient and were subject to very significant and legitimate criticism by Australian business. The Government has something of a preference in the present situation for relying on more general policy responses including, 'of course, the size of Government demands 'on our loan markets. Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: THE SHELL COMPANY OF AUSTRALIA
text: I also desire to put a question to the Treasurer. I refer him to last week's announcement that the Shell Company of Australia Limited has been asked to offer 25 per cent of its equity to Australian interests. Will the Treasurer tell the House whether naturalising status was discussed with Shell, in terms of a 25 per cent equity sale, or whether it is the intention of the Government to accord natural ising status to Shell once it realises a 25 per cent qualifying level of Australian equity? Will the Government grant naturalising status to Shell, or any other foreign company, without specific and irrevocable commitments to wind down the foreign equity to a maximum 49 per cent? Finally, does the Treasurer realise that, without such commitments, Shell with natural ising status would be in a position to take up 100 per cent equity in Australian projects where now it is limited to 50 per cent and naturally without diminishing the control structure one iota?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: THE SHELL COMPANY OF AUSTRALIA
text: The answer to the first part of the honourable gentleman's question is no. I simply repeat that an invitation has been extended to the Shell company to discuss the possible introduction of up to 25 per cent Australian equity in that company. It has not been made a condition of the two foreign investment approvals that I announced last week. So far as the natural ising rules are concerned, Shell is affected by those rules in precisely the same way as any other company. If it complies with the naturalising rules in every respect and wants naturalising status, it can have it. If it does not, it will not. NA

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: ISRAELI SOVEREIGNTY
text: Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a report in the Australian of 4 August 1981 dealing with the formation of the new Israeli Government, in which it is stated: In another important move. the new coalition has agreed to prodaim Israeli sovereignty over the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. "five years after implementing autonomy" for its Palestinian residents. Has the Minister attempted to verify whether this report is an accurate statement of the views of the Israeli Government? If this report accurately represents the views of the Israeli Government, does the Australian Government approve of any proposal by Israel to annex unilaterally the West Bank or Gaza? If it does not, what steps has the Government taken, or will it take, to make evident its disapproval of any such proposal?

Speaker: Mr STREET
Title: ISRAELI SOVEREIGNTY
text: I have seen the article to which the honourable gentleman referred concerning LIMITED the formation of the new Israeli Government and the likely policy of that Government towards the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The guidelines, which I understand have been issued by the new Israeli Government for the future of the West Bank and Gaza, include a declaration that the Government will work for the renewal of negotiations for full autonomy. This declaration is followed by statements along the lines that the autonomy agreed upon at Camp David means neither sovereignty nor self-determination. There is also a reference that, at the end of the five year transition period set down in the Camp David agreements, Israel will raise its claim and realise its act of sovereignty over Judea and Samaria, they being the historical names for the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. It is Australia's hope that the autonomy negotiations will recommence in the near future. We support the view that the outcome of these' negotiations should make proper provision for the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people. As far as we can judge, the guidelines issued by the new Israeli Government appear to indicate a change in its approach to the negotiations and it seems as though this change will make it more difficult to make any progress in the negotiations. NA

Speaker: Mr LES JOHNSON
Title: NEUTRON BOMB
text: My question is directi!d to the Prime Minister. Did the Australian Government have any consultation with the Government of the United States before the decision was taken to produce the neutron bomb? If so, what was the official Australian attitude? Does the Prime Minister agree that, as this decision has dramatically accelerated the arms race and seriously jeopardised world peace, it is against the interests of all Australians and indeed all humanity?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: NEUTRON BOMB
text: I would not surprise the honourable gentleman by indicating that I do not agree with the substance of his question or the conclusions contained in it. The threat to world peace has come from a Soviet Union that for decades has been spending 12 per cent to 14 per cent of its total income on defence and defence preparations. When United States expenditure on defence has gone down, Sbviet Union expenditure on defence has gone up. Throughout the period of detente-a period when people, whatever illusions they were under, genuinely believed that the world was entering into a safer phase-the expenditure of the Soviet Union on arms went up. It spent 12 per cent to 14 per cent of its national income on defence and offensive weapons year after year. That has not altered. The honourable gentleman would need only to look at the buildup of Soviet arms in the Warsaw Pact countries-the number of tanks, aircraft and divisions-to know quite well that any hope of Western European security can be achieved only by having tactical nuclear weapons of one kind or another because, on the basis of conventional arms, there would be no hope in the world of any valid defence of Western Europe. If the honourable gentleman wants to take the position that Western Europe should be naked to the arms of the Soviet Union and the other Warsaw Pact countries, with their tanks and guns outnumbering those of the West manifold, let the honourable gentleman argue that in France, Germany or other countries in Europe. It is worth noting that the new socialist Presiwould dent of France has taken a much tougher stand against Soviet militarism than was the case with his predecessor. Having in mind his socialist osophy, I think we should give weight to what he and his Foreign Minister have indicated and said about the nature of France's policy in relation to those matters. Neutron technology is not possessed only by the United States. I understand that that technology is also within the possession of the Soviet Union. Tactical nuclear missiles are stationed throughout Europe. If there is available new weaponry which can be more direct in its impact with less fall-out in relation to people who otherwise would be in a sense innocents in a struggle than would be the case with the present tactical nuclear weapons, I think .the honourable gentleman would be bold indeed if he tried to advance the argument that the Western powersthe North Atlantic Treaty Organisation powers and the United States-should leave the massive superiority in arms-conventional and, many would argue, nuclear as well-in the hands of the Soviet Union and its imperial empire. That is not the view of this Government. It would not be the view of the majority of the Australian people. NA NA

Speaker: Mr HARRIS
Title: ARRANGEMENTS
text: I refer the Minister for Health to the health insurance arrangements which are to commence on I September. Is he aware that one of the major Victorian health insurance funds announced this morning its new contribution rates? Can he say when the other funds will announce their rates so that the public will be in a position before 1 September to compare the rates of the various health insurance funds?

Speaker: Mr MACKELLAR
Title: ARRANGEMENTS
text: I noted that a major registered health insurance fund in Victoria announced its rates this morning. I am very pleased that some of the dire predictions of the Jeremiahs, particularly in the Opposition, have proved to be ill-founded. In fact, when one takes into account the 32c in the $1 rebate available for people taking out health insurance with registered health insurance funds, the cost to the family will be less than the cost during the last financial year. I am very pleased to see that, in fact, this particular fund has come up with rates which are attractive and which, in facl, give the lie to some of those rather exaggerated statements which allege that the cost to the individual and the family would be excessive. I believe there is a very urgent need for the funds to announce their rates as soon as possible. I like to make it clear that the announcement of the rates must come from the funds themselves. Whilst I and the Department approve the philrates we do not approve the timing of the announcement of those rates. The majority of the funds throughout Australia have lodged their applications for the approval of their rates. Those applications are being processed as quickly as possible by my Department. A number of major funds have had their rates approved and have not yet announced them. I would hope that they would announce those rates rather than try to secure some imaginary advantage by withholding the announcement. I hope they will announce them as soon as possible. I would hope that the funds that have not yet supplied my Department with their rates would do so as quickly as possible so that the public can have the opportunity to shop around. I might say in conclusion that the public have the opportunity to make a choice between competing funds. That element of choice is a very significant factor in the development of the new health scheme. That element, of course, would not be available under the Australian Labor Party's schemes. NA

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: VIETNAM
text: I direct the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a statement made to Thai leaders in the last 48 hours by the United States Under Secretary of State, Mr James Buckley, that Washington would have no serious objections to a further military strike by China against Vietnam. Will the Minister protest to Washington in the strongest possible terms pointing out that a further military incursion by China into Vietnam would be against Australia's interests; that a war in that area would our region and would cause massive outflows of refugees which it would be beyond our resources to handle? Further, in the spirit of peace in the area, will the Minister urgently consider an Australian initiative, I suggest in concert wit4 Japan, to promote negotiation rather than confrontation between Vietnam and the Association of South East Asian Nations and thereby lay the basis for a peaceful settlement in Kampuchea?

Speaker: Mr STREET
Title: VIETNAM
text: J have not been able to get confirmation of the statement to which the honourable gentleman has referred. Obviously, Australia has a very direct interest in maintaining peace and stability in South-East Asia. I remind the honourable gentleman that, but for the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea, we would be in a much better position than we are in today. It is that country's invasion of Kampuchea which is the greatest single cause of instability in South East Asia. As to the honourable gentleman's suggestion relating to Australia acting in concert with Japan and in relation to the relationship between ASEAN and Vietnam, I remind the honourable gentleman that, amongst the outcomes of the recent international conference on Kampuchea, two outcomes were relevant. One was the establishment of an intercessional committee. It is expected that the conference will resume in due course after the United Nations General Assembly meeting some time next year to pursue the possibilities of a peaceful settlement in Kampuchea. Secondly, there was a declaration from the conference-I am not sure whether it is in the form of the declaration or part of the communique from the conference-that contact on a bilateral basis in the region should be pursued to see whether that process could lead anywhere. For our part we have made known to the chairman of the intercessional committee that Australia stands ready to assist in any way we can should we be asked to do so. BIRDSVILLE: RADIO NA

Speaker: Mr IAN CAMERON
Title: TELEPHONE FACILITIES
text: I ask the 'Mi-ister for Communications a question. As the Minister for Housing and Construction and I have recently discovered, the radio telephone facilities from Birdsville to the outside world are quite inadequate with only one channel operating. As the races are to be held on 4 and 5 September and as the right honourable member for Wannon may have to go camping there again after tonight, will the Minister please see that Telecom Australia upgrades this most important communications destabilise link to the people of Birdsville?

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: TELEPHONE FACILITIES
text: I do not think that the right honourable member for Wannon will need to go camping after tonight. However, he might well want to go to the Birdsville races for other reasons. There are about 44,000 Australians living in remote and isolated areas of Australia who virtually have no telephone services at the moment. There are significant difficulties in trying to provide telephones for some of those people. About 66 per cent of them, I gather, .are Aboriginals, some of whom live a semi-nomadic lifestyle. Obviously it would be somewhat difficult to provide subscriber trunk dialling telephone services for them. Telecom has ideas of installing about two and a half thousand more automatic telephone exchanges. It hopes to have them equipped throughout Australia by about 1990. Two new developments in this field will certainly help Birdsville and other remote areas. One of these is called the digital radio concentrator system, for which three trial equipment-programs are now in hand. This system apparently provides a significantly improved access to radio in remote areas. Apparently the range of and the sound recorded on this digital radio concentrator system are considerably better than are now available on the high frequency service in operation. Telecom has high hopes that it will improve the services in the outback. In addition, in the first generation satellite there will also be some lines that will, I hope, extend the services in areas where the cost of land lines is now so high. I can assure the honourable member that,whatever the intention of the right honourable member for Wannon is in relation to camping or other matters, telecommunication services for his constituents amI those at Birdsville and elsewhere shortly will be at least significantly better. NA

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: POVERTY IN AUSTRALIA
text: I draw the Prime Minister's attention to the front page of today's Agewhich refers to the Zarb family, living in my electorate, with which I am acquainted and which lives in dire poverty. Since this family is typical of over two million Australians living below the poverty line set by Professor Henderson, I ask: Does the Government care at all about the poor in this country? When will we see action to help the poor of Australia who are the victims of this Government's economic policies?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: POVERTY IN AUSTRALIA
text: My colleague the Minister for Social Security will be making a statement in the Senate concerning a report prepared by the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat which is relevant to some of the allegations made in the honourable gentleman's question. I think there are a number of points that can and ought to be made. In introducing the system of family allowances, we redirected assistance in this country from the wealthy to the poorer sections of the Australian community. All honourable gentlemen will know quite well that the earlier system of tax rebates assisted better-off families in the middle higher tax paying brackets and that there were many families not paying sufficient tax to benefit from the rebates then offering. A number of families which were not in the tax-paying arena benefited very significantly as a result of that social change. In addition, the budgetary provISIons of this Government in the areas of the disadvantaged and the disabled have provided significantly greater funds as each year has passed. This Government introduced indexation of pensions and made thatÂ· a matter of law to protect pensioners and those in need of help from this Parliament from erosion of their living standards. It is this Government which has assisted many organisations in the community to build record numbers of homes for elderly citizens so that they can live their old age in dignity and decency and with self-esteem. I know the thing in all this which hurts the Australian Labor Party is that many of these initiatives in the area of social welfare represent initiatives of an imaginative kind which the Australian Labor Party never even thought of. INDUSTRY PRODUCTION, NA

Speaker: Mr BURR
Title: DISTRIBUTION AND EXCHANGE
text: My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does the Government have any plans to socialise the means of industry production, distribution and exchange? Is there any way by which industry production, distribution and exchange can be socialised by democratic means?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: DISTRIBUTION AND EXCHANGE
text: At the moment there are many countries around the world in very real economic difficulties. It is worth noting, I think, that whatever the political systems presently operating, government-run enterprises are the ones in greatest difficulty in nearly any country one could name. In many countries around the world, government-run enterprises in motor industries, in iron and steel industries and in coal industries are the ones absorbing vast sums of taxpayers' funds because of the inefficiency of the enterprise, because of the inadequacy of government management and because governments have felt that since they own the operation it is fair enough to pour taxpayers' dollars, billions upon billions of them, into supporting enterprises that were failing and unprofitable and which obviously should have undergone very substantial management changes and restructuring. Of course, if one wants to go to the socialist countries where everything is run by government, one can see a situation whereby the living stanto dard of people is much less than that which is provided through the free market private enterprise system. Let me say only that this Government has no intention of introducing reforms of the kind contained in the honourable gentleman's question, reforms which I know the honourable gentleman was not advocating, and reforms which are very much part of the philosophy of the Australian Labor Party and which would have the direct result of lowering the living standard of every Australian family from one end of this country to the other. REFUSAL. BY SENATE TO PASS NA

Title: BUDGET

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: BUDGET

Title: BUDGET

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: BUDGET

Therefore, there was an obligation on the parties which were then in opposition to do what they did. If the Australian Labor Party takes certain actions, those actions will be on its own head. Title: SAND MINING ON MORETON ISLAND

Is he aware also that, despite the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational value of the island, the Queensland Government has approved sand mining of 6.4 per cent of the island, which represents 1,200 hectares or 50 per cent of the island's beaches? If so, is it a fact that any application for the issue of export permits would necessarily be subject to the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and any decision by the Minister in regard to Moreton Island must be subject also to section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: SAND MINING ON MORETON ISLAND
text: There is an understanding between the Commonwealth and the State as to how to proceed with environmental impact statements. Examinations take place. If these examinations are satisfactory and an export licence is sought, approval is given. TRANSPORT WORKERS UNION: WAGE NA

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: CLAIM
text: I address the following question to the Prime Minister: Firstly, as strong allegations are circulating concerning the Prime Minister's personal involvement during the last week in the Transport Workers Union claim for a $20 wage increase and as I am aware of the basis of these allegations, will he tell the House what conversations he had in that period with employers and the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on how the granting of the Transport Workers Union claim could be accelerated in the Commission? Secondly, as the Prime Minister has apparently perceived the justice of this claim and has acted to expedite its satisfaction, will he intervene personally in the same way where the justice of other claims is at least as obvious or will we have to wait for the wedding of Prince Andrew?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: CLAIM
text: The honourable gentleman's question carried some impli:cations which are not correct. One of the things that he may regret is that this Government has established, under Mr Dolan's presidency of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, a capacity to have discussions with the ACTU and its officers in a way which contributes to a resolution of difficulties and in which nobody leaves meetings seeking to grandstand or score points against one party or the other. The capacity to talk in that way in a matter of confidence is essential if there are to be constructive discussions from time to time between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government. I must say that on a number of occasions in the last four to five months such discussions have taken place, and I have no intention of revealing here or anywhere else what took place in those discussions because they were between the ACTU and the Government. The same matters were relevant to the discussions that were held with the Confederation of Australian Industry by the Government. Quite plainly the Transport Workers Union dispute was one of the matters discussed on a number of occasions. But it seemed to me that all parties to this matter believed that it ought to go before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and that the Commission, which had made earlier judgments in these matters, ought to be the body that would make any future determination affecting the fortunes of the Transport Workers Union. The Government, I believe, has been able to establish with the Australian Council of Trade Unions a relationship which I regret it was not possible to establish during the presidency of the honourable member for Wills. NA

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: AIDS FOR THE DISABLED
text: I draw the attention of the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to the fact that this is the International Year of Disabled Persons. I ask: Is it a fact that import protection levels on aids for the disabled such as wheelchairs and driving aids are as high as 36 per cent? Is any consideration being given to removing this burden or converting this protection to a bounty?

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: AIDS FOR THE DISABLED
text: The question raised by the honourable member was canvassed in the House during the last sitting when I indicated to the House, particularly in relation to wheelchairs, that there were special provisions which enabled a person to make an import if his physician guaranteed that it was a warranted case. I recommend to him the speech I made on that occasion. NA

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a statement by Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia, published by the official Saudi newsagency on 7 August, describing the Camp David agreements as having 'proved to be a failure' and as being 'futile as a framework for a just and comprehensive peace in the Middle East'? In view of such an unqualified judgment by this leader of the Saudi Government, will the Government reject assertions that the multinational peacekeeping force, so described, proposed by the agreements to be based in the Sinai is secretly approved by moderate Arab governments? Does not Prince Fahd's statement also give substance to the argument that Australia's participation in the peacekeeping force will affect-probably jeopardise-our standing with the Arab world?

Speaker: Mr STREET
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: I think it has to be recognised that while the withdrawal of Israel from the Sinai was the principal reason for the establishment of the multinational force and observers, now in the jargon usually called the MFO, that in itself will not solve the Middle East problem. It needs to be part of an ongoing process. The Government is very conscious of that and has made those views known on more than one occasion. As I have made clear in this House, the attitude of Arab governments other than Egypt to the multinational force is of great importance to Australia because of the commercial links we have with that part of the world. The Government is still engaged in seeking reactions from those countries. NA

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Title: MEAT INDUSTRY
text: Is the Minister for Primary Industry able to inform the House whether he or his predecessor, the right honourable member for New England, advised the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council that the Government was prepared to re-examine the question of the meat industry paying for meat inspection charges if circumstances changed? As circumstances have clearly changed for the worse in the meat industry, when will the Minister announce such a reexamination? Why is the Minister not prepared to give assistance to this vital export industry, not prepared to help the 10,000 or more meat workers who have been stood down and not prepared to do anything to help the country towns so dramatically affected by the collapse of abattoirs?

Speaker: Mr NIXON
Title: MEAT INDUSTRY
text: Because of the drought over the last couple of years there has been a marked reduction in the number of cattle in Australia. That number, having reached some 33 million head a couple of years ago, is now down to some 24 million head. This has caused a shortage of supply for some of the abattoirs operating, particularly in New South Wales but also in other States. I have been drawing attention to the prospective difficulties faced by the abattoir industry for some months. Indeed, when I opened the National Agricultural Outlook Conference in January, I specifically referred to the problem that would occur following the downturn in cattle numbers and the restocking that would follow the breaking of the drought. So the abattoir industry is in difficulty, a similar sort of difficulty to that which a number of primary industries faced in earlier days. I have said consistently that there are far too many abattoirs in the country and that there will have to be a rationalisation of those abattoirs. This has been occurring. Some 25, I think, have now closed their doors. Some have closed permanently and some will open again. Further rationalisation will occur. The Meat Council of Australia has presented me with a submission for the Government. It has come back in later days with a further submission, I think to me and also to the Minister for Trade and Resources and to the Prime Minister. The Government will give serious consideration to the information that has come to hand in later days from the Meat Council of Australia and will respond positively to it in some way. The honourable member also asked whether I or my predecessor gave some words of comfort to the abattoir sector of the meat industry. I certainly did not do so. I will check positively with my colleague, the former Minister for Primary Industry, to see what he may have said on the matter. If something has been said, that, of course, will be taken into account when the Government further discusses the matter. NA

Speaker: Mr WEST
Title: SAND MINING ON MORETON ISLAND
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and Resources. It follows his answer to the question asked earlier by the honourable member for Griffith. Does the Minister fully understand that sections 26, 30 and 31 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 require him not to take any action which adversely affects a place that is part of the national register? As the Associated Minerals Consolidated and Minerals Deposits Ltd sand mining projects are economically insignificant and as Moreton Island is to be gazetted by the Australian Heritage Commission for the National Estate next Tuesday, will the Minister, considering his responsibilities under the Australian Heritage Commission Act, now assure us that he will discharge his duty under the Act and refuse any application for sand mining on Moreton Island now or in the future?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: SAND MINING ON MORETON ISLAND
text: Under the Australian Heritage Commission Act the only requirement is notification of an area. The Commonwealth has no power ultimately to restrict activity on any land. That is a sovereign right of the States. The Commonwealth does have power to restrict exports if the activity involves any exports. In the case of Moreton Island, no application for exports is before the Commonwealth for consideration at the moment. NA

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: PRESENTATION OF BUDGET

You will recall that last year I raised the matter that honourable senators were provided with copies of the Budget Speech at 8 p.m. and were in fact able to sit in the Gallery of this House and read the Speech while that right was denied to honourable members. lask you, Mr Speaker, whether you will discuss this matter with the Treasurer and whether members of this House will be treated as being equal to members of the Senate.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: THE NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE
text: I present the sixth report of the Joint Standing Committee on the new Parliament House relating to the revised design brief and to schematic design. Ordered that the report be printed. NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSENA Ministerial Stat-ment

Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Title: SCHEMATIC DESIGN REPORT
text: For the information of honourable members, I present the schematic design report for Australia's new Parliament House. I seek leave to make a statement in relation to the report. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Title: SCHEMATIC DESIGN REPORT
text: I thank the House. Mr Speaker, the Parliament House Construction Authority and its design and construction consultants have completed a major examination, refinement and development of the competition winner's design. This is the culmination of a year's work and represents the completion of a major design phase, known as the schematic design. The schematic design establishes the main design parameters and determines the overall layout of the building. Whilst there will still be some limited scope for minor detailed changes, these must and will be closely monitored to minimise or eliminate any cost implications. The schematic design retains the outstanding symbolic and architectural concepts which so distinguished the competition submission. The functional aspects of the design have been subjected to a rigorous examination by all building users and confirm the inherent efficiency of the competition submission. It is my hope that this report and a separate report by the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House will result in Parliament's agreeing to proceed with the construction of this exciting and much needed building. The design has been acclaimed as a building for the 21st century and beyond and will be the focal point for world attention when it is completed. It will be a measure of Australia's standing not only in architecture but also as a developed nation. MR FREDERICK WALTER TEMPERLY: NA

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: RETIREMENT
text: In July last Mr Frederick Walter Temperly, Administrative Officer of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, retired from parliamentary service. Fred Temperly served in Hansard for 26 years and as Administrative Officer for the last 13 years. His Public Service career began in 1937 when he joined the Attorney General's Department. For a few months in 1939 he served in the Joint House Department of the Parliament. He enlisted in the Australian Infantry Forces in . 1942 and served in New Guinea. Upon discharge from the AIF, he returned to the Public Service and joined Hansard in 1955. Any honourable member who made regular visits to the Hansard office would have had frequent contact with Fred Temperly and could not fail to be impressed by his courtesy and efficiency. The worth of his service to Hansard cannot be overstated. Most reporters would have sought his advice daily on procedural matters. The Parliament and Hansard in particular, wish Fred and Mrs Temperly a long and rewarding retirement.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: RETIREMENT
text: On behalf of Government members, I extend to Mr and Mrs Temperly our best wishes for their retirement. I thank Fred for his long years of devoted service as Administrative Officer within Hansard. I also mention our appreciation of the work he undertook on behalf of us all. There is no doubt that many people about this place are quite critical to the effective functioning of Parliament. Mr Temperly was one such person, working in Hansard, who did not have the opportunity of speaking in this place; yet without his services it would have been impossible for those of us who do speak to have our messages recorded and perhaps rewritten in a form that was far more legible than the words we used. I extend my personal best wishes to Mr and Mrs Temperly and wish them well.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Title: RETIREMENT
text: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) has allowed me to speak on behalf of the Opposition. I particularly mention the close association with Mr Temperly of the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) and myself. All honourable members on this side of the House have a great respect for Fred Temperly. We regret his early retirement. I think it is sad that this Parliament has lost the services of Fred Temperly so early when that loss was not necessary. As honourable members know, Fred Temperly is a stubborn man and a very proud man. He felt that a proposed promotion that was to be given to him in Hansard was not accepted generally by certain Hansard staff. For that reason, he took a very principled stand. We hope that in the future this Parliament will again have the services of Mr Temperly, perhaps in a consultative position. All honourable members on this side of the House acknowledge how we appreciated his great tolerance and patience with us. I think the Hansard writers will miss his great wisdom in procedural matters because nobody in this Parliament understood the forms and procedures as Fred did. We wish Fred and his wife a happy retirement. We hope that in time we may consult with him and he will again help us.
