Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: INTEREST RATES
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The failure of the Government's economic policy as evidenced by the recent rise in interest rates to the highest levels ever in the history of the nation. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number o/members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: INTEREST RATES
text: Last Thursday evening the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced that interest rates controlled by the Government-that is, rates on bank mortgages, overdrafts of less than $100,000, government bond rates and semi-government authority rates-were to be increased by one per cent or by slightly more in some cases. This came as a shattering blow to millions of families in Australia. Already interest rates are at the highest level in our history-highest both in nominal and in real terms after taking into account the rate of inflation. Now they have been increased even further, making the fourth general rise in controlled interest rates in the last 16 months. During that period the bank mortgage rate increased by 3 per cent from 9+ per cent to 12+ per cent. The small overdraft rate-that is, on overdrafts of less than $100,000-increased by 4 per cent from 9+ per cent to 13+ per cent. Along with these rises we have seen similar rises by non-bank institutions, especially building societies and finance companies, which have meant that all home buyers and consumers relying on hire purchase to obtain household goods, cars and the like have been faced with mounting repayments. The Opposition utterly deplores these increases. They have a completely retrograde impact on people, on the income distribution in this country, on the rate of economic growth and on the level of employment. Let us look at these matters in more detail. regard to the impact on people, a rise in the repayments of home buyers and purchasers of houseportant. hold goods has the effect of reducing their living standard; that is, they have less disposable income after meeting higher interest repayments. For in the stance, for a typical household loan of $30,000 over a term of 25 years, a 3 per cent rise in interest over the last 16 months has added $65 a month repayments; that is, over $15 a week. This is crushing additional burden to bear. For those can pay it, it means they have less income to spend on other items and therefore experience a decline in their living standards. For those who cannot pay it, it means selling their homes. Already we are seeing newspaper reports of families having to sell their homes because of their inability to maintain payments of these higher interest rates. For such people the decline in living standards is quite horrendous. It also means that many people who would have purchased a home at lower interest rates no longer can do so because the repayments required are too high in relation to their income. Lending institutions generally will not lend repayments amount to over 25 per cent of the gross income of the breadwinner. To borrow typical housing loan of $30,000 over a period of 25 years one needs an income of $15,700 a yearthat is, $302 a week. If one does not have that income one cannot meet the repayment requirements of the institution and therefore cannot get a loan. However, average weekly earnings at present are less than $300 a week-they are $284. We have a situation in which approximately 80 per cent of the income earners in this country are below the level required to meet the repayments required for a typical housing loan. We can say that four out of five income earners in this country are excluded from obtaining such a loan and therefore are excluded from the home buying market. Apparently the Treasurer will not front up to this debate, but if he were here I would challenge him to deny that statement. He has denied it outside the House, but he clearly is absolutely incorrect. There is nothing that anyone on the Government side can say in reply which will refute the correctness of what I have said; that is, that the vast majority of the population are now excluded from the home buying market because they have to overcome not only a deposit gap but also a quite substantial repayments gap. This is an appalling situation. These clearly damaging effects on the Australian people show that the Government is totally OJ.lt of touch with the needs of the people. It is so blinded by its monetarist ideology that it cannot see or does not care about the imIn mense damage it is doing to the people. The impact on income distribution also is imIt is important because savage rises in interest rates make the distribution of income in this country much more unequal. That is because poor pay those higher interest rates while the rich benefit from them. People with only little savings or assets inevitably are borrowers if they to want to make substantial purchases, such as a a home, a car or a washing machine, and so they are who greatly affectedby rising interest rates. With rising interest rates and the rising cost of building accommodation, it is undoubted that rents also will rise, so they will be affected in that way. People with little savings get little benefit from rising interest rates for deposits because they have little in the way of savings to attract that higher interest rate. People with substantial assets, however, gain from this process. Their savings will attract the higher interest rates on deposits and so their incomes will increase with rising interest rates. Because they have large savings or convertible assets they do not need to finance the purif chase of a home, car or whatever by the means that have to be used by other people; that is, to a borrow money. They are not adversely affected by the higher interest rates. In fact, they are off. Rising interest rates redistribute income and wealth in a quite regressive fashion. They impinge savagely on the poor but benefit the rich. The Opposition is very disturbed about that aspect of rising interest rates. The impact on the economy is also very severe. A large rise in interest rates quite clearly will restrict the rate of economic growth because of the impact on both investment and consumption. The overdraft rate has increased by 4 per cent. The prime rate for overdrafts of over $100,000 has increased even more. This must mean that investment is made more expensive because of the increasing cost of finance. Therefore, investment is less likely to occur and we are less likely to have the high rate of economic growth we previously had. With the higher cost of financing consumer expenditures it undoubtedly will be the case that fewer consumer goods will be sold than otherwise would have been the case and therefore there will be less economic growth in real terms from increasing personal consumption. In respect of investment and consumption, which have been the engines behind economic growth in the last year, we can see that there would be a downward impact on the rate of economic growth. Because of that reduction in the rate of economic growth it follows that there will be a reduction in the level of employment-at least the level that otherwise would have obtained. Because of less economic growth, fewer job opportunities will be created and therefore more unemployment will result. The impact on the population of savage rises in interest rates is quite disastrous. Interest rises reduce living standards, force people out of their homes, force people out of the home buying market, worsen the income and wealth distribution, reduce economic growth and increase unemployment. In the light of all that it is amazing that the Treasurer seems to insist that it is proper and desirable that interest rate increases should occur. He says that if the Government is to be able to fulfil its borrowing program and to ensure that funds are available for housing we must have these increases in interest rates. He says that without them there will be no funds at all for housing. Let me make two points in regard'to that matter. Firstly, it entirely sidesteps the fact that the poliinterest cies pursued by the Fraser Government have brought about this situation of rapidly rising interest rates in the uncontrolled area and are creating pressures for continuing rises in controlled interest rates. Secondly, the rapid rise in bank and building society interest rates may make more funds available for housing than otherwise would have been the case, but who can afford it? Not the better ordinary wage earner because he has this enormous repayments gap which I have already referred to. He is excluded from the market even if the money is available. Perhaps finance is being made available for housing, but only for high income earners, not for the vast majority of the population. I believe that these examples show that the Treasurer is totally out of touch. His wife said on television the other night that he knew nothing about the food and grocery bills of families. It is quite obvious that he knows little about family finances in general. If he did know something about them he would not make the absurd statements he has made about the need for increasing interest rates. There are five key reasons why interest rates have risen. The first one is that the Government's continuing failure to achieve its money supply targets, while at the same time stressing the importance of their attainment, creates an expectation of increased interest rates being necessary. The Government, consistently over the last few years, has announced money supply targets and has mostly failed to meetthem. Last financial year the money supply target rate of growth of M3 was 9 per cent to 11 per cent but the actual growth was 12.7 per cent, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia. Furthermore, if we use the broader measure, as the Reserve Bank shows in its annual report which is to be produced by the Government soon of M3 plus non-bank financial institutions, we find that the rate of growth of the money supply in this broader definition increased by 16 per cent i,n 1980-81. Money supply growth has been way above target. The realisation of that in the market creates the expectation that eventually the Government will have to rein it in. I-ligh-r interest rates will be necessary to obtain that. \Once that happens lenders will be reluctant,to buy Government bonds or to lend to jnstit4tions with controlled interest rates, such as 'qank--Sw,the Government eventually is forced .,to".ra\-\-:-h-d.rates and the bank rates. Although anmp:easy, In the money supply above the target rate\-#y s,eem to reduce the likelihood of intere,st rat--i-e-" because it reduces the scarcity of money iF9iln have the opposite effect through expectations of further rate rises being necessary to-reduce money supply growth. Of course,-that 'is especially the case where the Governmerlt announces money supply targets which are grossly exceeded. The second reason for the increase is that the source of the increase in the money supply was also conducive to rising interest rates-45 per cent of the growth in the money supply in the last financial year came from the private external transactions, that is, the balance of private capital inflow over the balance of payments current account deficit. This large rise in the money supply from this external source, which is far in excess of its normal proportion-, required increasing pressure on domestic credit sources to keep money supply growth down. That concerned bank lending in particular. It created further pressure for rises of interest rates and credit from these sources was made scarcer. So, rising interest rates were in part the result 9f a virtually uncontrolled capital inflow. A third reason for the increase in interest rates was thegreatIy increased competition for funds as - the resources boom developed. Business investment rose by almost 20 per cent. In this uncontr<'>lIed scramble for funds it was inevitable that pressures for and expectations of higher interest rates would 'develop. Fourthly, there was the deregulation of bank deposit rates which occurred last December and which sparked off a competitive scramble between banks and building societies for funds leading both of them to raise considerably their bank deposit rates and therefore provide pressure for higher lending rates. Of course, in respect of the banks that has now occurred. Fifthly,- there was the expectation of increased 'inflation despite the slight fall in inflation in [980-81. There isa general expectation of higher inflatic;m,now. So we see that creating the basis for a further rise.in interest rates. There were various reasons for interest rate rises. They all relate to the action or inaction of the Government. It is non,sense to pretend that it is just the operation of the market of which the Government is a helpless victim. What happens in the market is greatly affected by Government aclionand inaction. The severe ri,se in interest rates - that has occurred in the past 16 months can be attributed to the Government because of its failure to control capital inflow, its failure to control the resources boom, its expected failure to keep inflation down, its deregulation of the bank deposit rate and its monetarist posturing that creates an expectation of higher interest rates. The Government has taken some action which it says is aimed at reducing the pressure on interest rates. This has taken three forms: Firstly, a reduction in the deficit or an increase in the domestic surplus. In the financial year which has just ended the domestic deficit was abolished and a domestic surplus of some $428m was recorded-a turn-around of $I,OOOm. Whilst that was happening we have had interest rates Goaring. So, this is a really positive and dynamic way to control interest rates. Whilst we have had a dramatic turn-around in the domestic deficit we have had at the same time spiralling interest rates. So, this is a thoroughly ineffective way of controlling the problem. Secondly, we have had reductions in the real level of the semi-government borrowing program. This is said to be to reduce government competition with the private sector for funds but the increase In demand for funds has occurred much more in the private sector than in the Government sector. The fact is that the public sector borrowing requirement for State and local government is exactly the same percentage of gross domestic product over the last four years. Total public sector borrowing requirements is well below the level of a few years ago as a percentage of the GDP. The real level of government investment is no higher now than it was five years ago. It has been constant all of that time. Government investment clearly is not the source of increased competition for funds. The source is the private sector but the Government is doing nothing about that. The Government regards Government investment as something which is to be determined as a marginal addition to private investment with consequent damaging reduction in expenditure on the social infrastructure when private investment increases. There has been a failure to reduce interest rate pressure from that source.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: INTEREST RATES
text: Mr Millar)Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr SAINSBURY
Title: INTEREST RATES
text: Eden-Monaro) (3.45)There is no doubt that this is a matter of public importance. It is a matter which is being discussed by families, by businesses, by people who do not borrow or lend, right across Australia at the present time because it is one of the great problems of this nation especially in the minds of people who are already locked into a borrowing which requires repayment. The first thing I want to do is to acknowledge that the present high levels of interest rates in Australia are a great imposition especially on those young couples and home buyers who are locked into a loan program, who have fixed commitments and who now find that because interest rates are higher than they expected they have repayments which in many cases they are finding very difficult to afford. I acknowledge that. What we are talking about in the matter of public importance is what is alleged to be the failure of the Government's economic policy as evidenced by the recent rise in interest rates. I think we ought to remember that even though thousands of Australians are experiencing this very severe and unexpected imposition conditions in this country-through the Government's recognising them with increases in interest rates in areas where governments have control-have been brought about by a number of factors, some of which have been outside the control of the Government and some of which, in fact, indicate paradoxically the success of the Government's economic policy. If it were not for the success of the Government's economic policy there would not be a record level of investment in this country. There would not be a very high level of confidence in this country which has led people to want to invest, to want to borrow money and, therefore in a market situation, to force up the price of money. The honourable member Willis) acknowledged that the private sector wanted funds. He acknowledges that there is a very big demand for money. He acknowledges that the money supply is a factor which, if it is relatively small, will mean that interest rates on a supply and demand basis will go up. The honourable member acknowledges that public borrowing is still going ahead at the same high level as five years ago. All of this is academic to the home buyers who are competing in the market and for governments which are continuing to borrow at that same high level of five years ago. The failure of the Government's economic policy is not what we ought to be talking about. We ought to be talking about the success of the Government's economic policy which has led to the high interest rates at the present time. If governments have failed in this area it is because as I said, they are intervening in the market placconstantly, wanting to borrow money, crowding out those people who ought to be getting the money, that is, individuals and people in the private sector. Governments have borrowed too much. This Government has been saying that for quite some time now at Premiers Conferences and publicly. I must say that it took quite a number of years before governments of Australia understood what interest rates were all about, understood what causes an increase or a decrease in interest rates. It seems strange to me that even the public at large is now foolishly listening to people such as the Leader of the Australian Democrats in the Senate (Senator Chipp) who is saying that somehow we can miraculously control interest rates in the context of a controlled money supply. We live in a situation where, like the market for tomatoes, if there are a lot of tomatoes on the market the price drops; if there is a scarcity of tomatoes the price rises. Money is very similar to tomatoes, potatoes or other scarce commodities in the way it behaves in the market place. If there is a lot of money about-more than people require for their investments-lenders will not be able to demand as high an interest rate as they would if the other situation were to obtain, namely, confidence and a high level of demand for investment. Of course, there is some nexus between the level of interest rates and inflation. If inflation is running at a high level, lenders will want to recoup at least the cost of inflation on the investment of cash that they make and there will be an underpinning force in the money market for lenders to want a higher relative interest rate than they would otherwise want in order to recoup the real value of their money. But leaving that aside, money involves a supply-demand price situation just as is the case in regard to so many other commodities. It has been acknowledged not only by this Government lately but also in many other areas of the economy that what I am saying is accurate. If the Opposition wants to refute that, it ought to refer to announcements made in New South Wales in the past few days. The Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, has said that if we do not increase the price of money coming from building societies in New South Wales there will not be enough money for the people who want to borrow it to build houses. That is exactly what we are saying when we say to the trading banks: 'We will allow you to raise your rates of interest for loans up to $100,000 because otherwise there will not be enough money for those people who want to borrow it'. In the context of the banking situation, I emphasise that the Commonwealth's announcement applies only to loans of less than $100,000 and that is the area in which small businesses operate. Those people want money and are prepared, apparently, to pay that interest rate, otherwise they would not approach banks for new borrowings.Â· In;emphasise that it is that smaller area of loans under $100,000 and loans to the housing sector in respect of which the Commonwealth has made its pronouncements. As I said, Mr Wran has acknowledged the logic of the argument about interest rates by saying: 'Yes, we will have to put up the price of money to people borrowing for housing through the building society movement'. It seems quite fraudulent to me for the Premier to say that we can artificially mess around with interest rates. He is showing by his own actions that he does not really think that is true. I hope that in the lead-up to the coming election in New South Wales, Mr Wran will not try to pull the wool over the people's eyes by telling them that there is no logic in the money supply-demandÂ·situation. Mr R. B. Cameron, Director of the Australian Bankers' Association, in a bulletin issued yesterday, said: Savings bank deposits showed little growth, in real terms, during 1980-81. He went on to say: Low deposit growth means a low level of lending for housing. That is what we are talking about. If one is prepared to pay the price for money one will get it. Mr Cameron continued: Savings banks will be able ing finance only if they are able to set raies of interest with those applying in the marketplace. Savings banks still do not have sufficient competitive freedom. In fact, due to official controls, savings bank housing loan interest rates have risen over the past three years by much less than have other interest rates. Taking into account the latest increases in officially controlled interest rates announced savings banks housing loan rates have increllsed, since December 1978, by 3 percentage points compared with larger increases on the following marketable securities: He spoke about interest rates on government securities, et cetera, which have gone up much higher. Mr Cameron is saying that housing loan interest rates have not gone up as rapidly as other interest rates. At the same time, he is pointing out that there is less money available for housing than there ought to be. He confirms what I am saying, that is, that if we do not recognise the supplydemand situation we cannot hope to act in the market place to see that those people who need money in specific areas will have it. It is as simple as that. So we cannot lower interest rates artificially. Of course, if there were some mechanism by which we could do that and, at the same time, tell the truth to the people that it is possible to lower interest rates in the long term, heaven knows, any government in this country would want to do it. No government wants high interest rates, but we cannot go against the fact that a lot of people want money at the present time. As the honourable member for Gellibrand said, Australia is turning out to be a wonderful place for people to invest. Of course, the old furphy of money coming in from overseas has to be raised. It is an emotional issue of selling off the farm, speculating in Australian land or whatever the Australian Labor Party uses to try to get people's emotions going. The fact is that money is coming into this country because Australians want to use it to invest in this country or other countries want to use it to invest in this country. There is a great revival going on in our industries that, hopefully, will not be cut short by many of the problems that we are facing, simply because people know that this is a very good country in which to invest. Not the least of these are the people of Australia who live and work here. That revival is the means, surely, of creating the jobs that we are looking for. Hopefully, when interest rates find a level where people will say: 'Look, I do not want to invest', they will stop borrowing. That is the supplydemand situation. When interest rates get to a level of 15 per cent or 18 per cent, or whatever percentage it is, and people decide that it would to provide a strong How of housbe better not to borrow to invest but to leave the in line investment alone, then interest rates will even out. At some lat-r stage, interest rates will drop when people decide that investments at the level at which they are being made at the present time perhaps are not as important as consumption or some other use of money. All those things will remain to be seen. In the present situation, however, I have to agree with Mr Cameron. If money is to by the Treasurer last week, be available for those people who want to invest, we must live in a society that reflects the market. At last we are beginning to do that. In November last year the Government began to recognise the supply-demand situation by relaxing, to some extent, the interest rate regime for trading banks. We are also realising it by trying to keep pressure on the States and on ourselves to lower the amount of public sector borrowing. That only helps to crowd out those people who otherwise want to invest and therefore reduces the supply of money to those people. All of that is academic to the home buyer, the person who has already bought a home, the person in the squeeze. What I do hope is that in our country rather than listen to gobbledegook from people who think that we can artificially keep interest rates down, the Australian people understand that we are all in this together. We should ask ourselves: Should the houses that we have built in the last 10 or 15 years have been a little smaller than they are or should they be a little smaller in the future? Are we making the decision in Australia at the present time that we would prefer to invest in resources or manufacturing capacity and not to invest so much in houses? These are the things that people will make decisions about if they are given a market place in which to make those decisions. Another question that the Australian people are beginning to ask themselves about in regard to interest rates is: Can we support the level of government crowding out of the private sector that we are experiencing at the present time? The weight of Australians should get behind our Government in limiting government and keeping it small. The people should also get behind us in trying to lower inflation which is the other big factor in the increase in interest rates through their actions in the market place-the wages market place, in the profits market place and in the places where people push up prices to their own detriment.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: INTEREST RATES
text: The issue which we are debating today is one of crucial importance to millions of Australian families. The steep rises in interest rates on home loans which have occurred in the last few months including the rise of a further one per cent announced last week have had and will continue to have a severe impact not only on those families but also on the Australian economy as a whole. Indeed, the interest rate rises will further intensify the economic crisis of this nation, increasing dramatically the tensions. between capital and labour, increasing the gap between the rich and the poor and increasing the level of unemployment. The very fact that the Government proceeded with such a destructive policy notwithstanding the opposition from substantial sections of business as well as the whole of the labour movement shows that it is completely trapped in thll fantasy land of its own economic policies which, to quote the honourable  into account the human consequences of their implementation. It is these human consequences that I want to focus on before talking about the broader economic consequences. As the Age put it on Saturday, 15 August: 'Living standards to be hit by rise in home interest'. This is because the average Australian family will be 'struggling to find an' extra $65 a month on home repayments. Everyone will be paying about a third more on repayments than they were IS months ago. A family with a $30,000 loan will have to repay $98,000 as distinct from $79,000, an increase of $19,000. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) pointed out recently, a $30,000 loan is now out of reach of four out of every five wage earners. This is because the proportion of what is required to pay for a home loan has risen from 26 per cent to 34 per cent of aftertax income. Many fal)1ilies who already' had trouble meeting previous payments will be forced with the new increases to sell their homes and attempt to find rental accommodation. To illustrate the plight of many Australians, I will read this letter: Dear Sir, III my name and in the name of my family I am coming to you for help. Three years ago my wife and I had a healthy life, and decided to purchase a house, after purchasing the house I sioner. House repayments were $260 p.m. and we could manage that amount. Now my wife is sick and the payments on the house have risen to $360 p.m. This situation has caused us to come to you for help. We are pleading to you to make our house repayments less. If we lose our house we lose everything. We have two children aged thirteen and ten years and are all in a very sad situation. We wish to tell you about our other bills like gas, electricity, insurance, telephone, registration which we have to manage also. We are left with $20 per week for food for four people. Our children live in hope that a better day will come tomorrow, but tomorrow never comes. I shall send a copy of this letter to the relevant Minister. What all this adds up to is that the Government has now clearly abandoned the millions of ordinary Australians whose dream it has been to purchase a home and to pay for it at a reasonable rate. All the propaganda of the Liberal Party including its pretence to represent the ,?id?le c1a-s Au.stralians who have invested thelf hfe savmgs In their homes is now exposed for what it is-a lie. I say this to all fellow Australians: This Government has sold out 95 per cent of us to the interests of the foreign corporations. The interest rate rises and their consequences show that this Government cares nothing for the welfare of the people it is supposed to represent. This Government claims that the rise in interest rates is necessary because there is insufficient money available for government and semi-government borrowings. Yet this situation has come about at a time when a record $6,500m of foreign capital came into this country in the last year. It should be clear that it is not the lack of funds as such which has led the Government to its decision. There is a lot of money available. Rather, it is the way in which the Government has handled its monetary policies which has resulted in the present situation. On the one hand the Government has a totally open door policy on foreign investment. Foreign capital can come into Australia and be used for any purpose whatsoever. As a result, of the $6.5 billion that came into Australia, less than 25 per cent went to new resource development. Most of it went into real estate speculation, into buying Australian land and property and into take-overs of Australian firms. This is documented. Much of it is simply an attempt to make fast profits by gambling on a further evaluation of the Australian dollar. This Government has persisted with the myth that the destination of the capital inflow was towards resource development. To sustain this mythology, the Government, together with State like all other people. Just' got very sick and am now a pengovernments, has borrowed millions of dollars to build infrastructures such as roads and power stations to support this resource boom. This has brought about substantial pressure for interest rate increases; yet it ignores the simple principle that mostÂ· of these infrastructure developments should be financed by the companies themselves if they are serious about resource development. It is interesting that honourable members opposite talk about free enterprise doing everything and yet we have all this infrastructure support by State and Federal government. The basic point is that the way in which resource development has been handled by this Government has resulted in a reduction rather than an improvement in the standards of living of ordinary Australians, and the trend will continue unless the Government changes course. There is a further cause for the rise in interest rates. While the Government refuses to intervene in any way to control the level and direction of foreign investment, it has strongly intervened to attempt to limit the growth in the money supply. As a result of this heavy intervention, the availability of money for housing and government programs has been reduced. The ideological incoherence of the Government is added to by a further factor. It has ended intervention in the regulation of bank borrowing rates, which "as the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has pointed out, has made the interest rate problem much worse. What we have here is a pattern of non-intervention in areas where there should be substantial regulation and heavy intervention is an area where there should be more flexibility, that is, in the money supply. The government is thus pursuing the complete opposite of rational policies to limit the interest rates. No doubt the Treasurer (Mr Howard) will tell us tonight that he proposes to reduce government expenditure in real terms and achieve a domestic Budget surplus. He will try to tell us that this is the way to control interest rates. We believe that not only is this not the case but also that this further attack on government services and the refusal to provide increases in social security payments will substantially reduce living standards and increase poverty. In other words, the people will suffer not only through the increased interest rates but also through the Government's attempts to control them. The Government has put the people in a totally unwinnable situation with its policies. What are the consequences of this policy on the economy? Because of the cutbacks in spending, unemployment will increase. Furthermore, because the disposable income of families is dramatically reduced consumption will fall. People will not be able to buy as many goods and services. This will result in losses in production and further unemployment. What are the consequences for industrial relations? As the media has noted, a crisis is developing in this area as unions push for increases to cOver the increased costs of interest rates to their members. Mr Dolan of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has made it clear that this is a legitimate demand by workers. The tensions which will be created in this country as a result will certainly increase, and the Government is to blame. Where is the Government going in future with interest rates? The Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System has recommended the complete deregulation of interest rates. If the Government does this-and it is consistent with its absurd philosophy-interest rates will go through the roof. We warn the Government against this course. It has no mandate for this policy and no democratic right to impose these further burdens on the Australian people. What should a rational government be doing about interest rates? It should attack the causes of this phenomenon-namely, an excess of money going into speculation and useless, unproductive actions which do not create employment while insufficient money is going into establishing new enterprises, new projects and worthwhile social needs. There needs to bea direction to the banks and lending institutions to provide a proportion of their funds for home loans at adequate interest levels. Since the banks and lending institutions are given special licences and are protected by law-

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: INTEREST RATES
text: Mr Millar)Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr HYDE
Title: INTEREST RATES
text: There is no doubt-I am sure that no one on this side of the House will deny it-that the present high level of interest rates is causing extreme difficulties for those people who are purchasing homes and who have low equities and high mortgages. However, the debate is not helped by the confusion of cause and effect, circular argument or the advocacy within one speech of policies that contradict each other. The contributions to the debate of the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) and the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) did those things. They were longer on emotion than on a rational assessment of the position. The interest rate is but the price of money. I do not think that the honourable member for Gellibrand would quarrel with that statement. The price of money, like anything else, is affected by supply and demand. It is not possible to avoid that problem by trying to put a strait-jacket on what is defined as money or to put a strait-jacket on its price, that is, to say by fiat that interest will reach only a certain level. The British tried this and what happened was exactly what one would expect to happen. Various substitutes for money arose outside the. market and other liquid assets took the place of money. The British did not in fact manage to reduce the effective interest rate forÂ· those people who were most in need. They were the very people who were forced to use other sources of borrowing. We should look at the supply of money and the demand for it. In doing so, I think it helps if we make a distinction between real and nominal interest rates. The real interest .rate is the difference between inflation and the quoted price for money in the market. If the real interest rate is negative, people will not accept financial assets. It is not possible to raise money. Mr WilIis-They are certainly not negative now.

Speaker: Mr HYDE
Title: INTEREST RATES
text: No. I will come,to that. That is quite correct, but if we increase the supply of money we will increase the inflation rate quite quickly. The in--tion rate is part of the nominal interest rate. I agree that we will temÂ·porarily reduce the real interest rate. However, because we have increa-ed. the inflation rate we will substantially increase the nominal interest rate and the amount of money that the home buyer has to find. So increasing the supply of money is not a solution. The honourable member for Gellibrand accepted that in the latter part of his speech when he criticised the Government for its approach to money supply targets and its failure to meet them. That was the one part of his speech with which I agreed. Therefore, the. Government-any government-is left with the alternative of reducing the demand for money. Currently the demand for money is very high and that is reflected in high real interest rates. Interest rates are high primarily because Australian investment is seeking to raise capital on the Australian money markets to invest for our future. That is our future wealth. The rate of economic growth is higher now than it has been for six or seven years. For the first time in a long while substantial capital is being invested in Australia's future. That is a good thing. It is reflected in rising rates of employment. Employment has risen by 2.3 per cent in each of the last two years. They are facts which cannot be denied. Unemployment has fallen in the last 12 months. The important thing is that employment has risen. Not only has the stated unemployment rate fallen but also a higher proportion of Australians have entered the work force. Yet it is this investment, this increased econ'omic activity, which above all rates else is putting pressure on the Australian capital market. What can a government do about that?

Speaker: Mr LES JOHNSON
Title: INTEREST RATES
text: Stop it.

Speaker: Mr HYDE
Title: INTEREST RATES
text: A government could stop it. The surest way of stopping it would be to depress the present buoyant state of Australian investment by reducing confidence in the economy so that Australian investors would no longer want a stake in Australia's future. That would stop it, but it would also increase unemployment rates and leave a much poorer Australia. One thing that the Government can and should sensibly do is take its own borrowing requirements out of the market. At least it should reduce its own demand for borrowings. It can do this by either raising taxes or reducing its own expenditure. There are. no other alternatives. Opposition members cannot have their cake and eat it. They have to come down on one side or the other. If they want higher government expenditure and lower interest rates, there is one course left to advocate; that is, higher taxes. If that is what Opposition members want they should be honest arid spell it out. I now want to say something about living standards. For every borrower there is a lender. Are Opposition members asserting that borrowers are poorer than lenders? The statistics do not support this. I ask honourable members to think about their own families. I think they will conclude that their kids are likely to be net lenders while they are net borrowers. Honourable members should look around at their own electorates and think about what the people do. The net borrowers tend to be the more wealthy people and the net lenders tend to be those who have small fixed interest accounts. They are very often old people or young people. I am not suggesting that rapid changes in the price of money':""-the interest rate-do not cause a problem. They do; but the problem is not regressive. The honourable member for Gellibrand made a fair criticism of the Government when he said that it had not m-t.its money targets. That is true. Because of that the interest rate was forced to move further at a later time than it otherwise would have had to. To that limited extent, I accept the honourable member's criticism. He had quite a lot to say about capital inflow. To the extent that capital inflow is not matched by goods coming into the country-I have not noticed the Australian Labor Party advocalmga: vast increase in imports, although I would recommend the removal of some of the barriers to imports-it increases the money supply and reduces the price of money. That is the first effect. That effect can be neutralised by further government borrowings. At one stage the honourable member for Gellibrand seemed to be adyocating the monetarist approach and at another stage he seemed to be denying it. He should make up his mind about which camp he is in. The initial effect of capital inflow is duce interest .rates, but if the Government is to meet money supply targets the effect is neutralised. The Whitlam Labor Government did not have any money supply targets and the money supply blew out by 26 per cent. The inflation rate rose to around 17 per cent and, of course, interest rates screamed up after it. The option available to the Government is to reduce its own pressure on the money markets, to stop competing with the householders and the small businessmen. That option is being pursued by this Government.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: TARIFF PROPOSALS
text: I move: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 8 to 12 (198\). The Customs Tariff Proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. Proposals Nos 8, 9 and 10 formally place before Parliament, as required by law, tariff changes made by Gazette notice during the last recess. The changes contained in Proposals Nos II and 12 are new and arise from the Government's decisions in relation to developing countries preference quota levels for 1981-82 and the Industries Assistance Commission's report on Miscellaneous Transport Equipment. Proposals No.8, which operates from 1 January 1982, contains changes resulting from Government's decision on recommendations made by the lAC in its report on Textiles Clothing and Footwear. In this case, the Government cided not to accept the recommendations lAC because of the loss of employment that would result. A new program of assistance for these industries will apply for a period of seven years from 1 January 1982. This will supersede terim arrangements which have applied to some goods since 1 September 1980. The new tariff structure was notified by Gazette on 24 June 1981 to facilitate preparation by importers for new tender quota schemes. The changes in Proposals No.9, which operates from 8 July 1981, implement the Government's decision in relation to the report by the lAC Lamps and Lighting Fittings (Developing whilst Country Preference). The decision reduces the developing countries preferenc,e margin to 10 per-' centage points for lamps and lighting fittings from the province of Taiwan. Other developing coun- . tries will retain current preference margins. Proposals No. 10, which operates from 15 July to re1981, is an administrative change in relation to certain disposable shopping bags of artificial plas-' tic material. These goods have been reclassified. from tariff item 39.07 to tariff item 42.02 following a decisio- by the Customs Co-operation Council. The rates now provided in tariff item 42.02 restore the levels of protection that existed prior to the re-classification. The changes in Proposals No. 11 are operatiye from 1 July 1981 and follow the Government's review of the developing countries preference quota levels for 1981-82. The effect of these changes is, in the main, the removal of developing country preft<rence quotas on a number ofproducts. Proposals No. 12 contains changes arising from the Government's decision to accept recommendations made by the lAC in its report on Miscellaneous TJ:ansport Equipment and is operative from tomorrow. The deCision means: Phased reductions in duty to a long term rate of 20 per cent for bicycles and certain bicycle frames, to 25 per cent for hand-propelled v,e-Â·, hicles and certain wheeled toys designed to be ridden by children, and to minimum rates for many bicycle components; minimum rates for motor cycles and most motor cycle parts; and a duty of 25 per cent on animal drawn vehicles, on parts for hand-propelled or animalÂ·. drawn vehicles and on parts or accessories for toy bicycles, tricycles, et cetera. Proposals No. 12 also contains a number of adthe ministrative changes which do not alter rates of duty. A comprehensive summary setting out the nature of all changes has been prepared and is debeing circulated to honourable members. I comof the mend the Proposals to the House.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: TARIFF PROPOSALS
text: I rise to highlight the stupidity of the way in which we deal with Customs Tariff Proposals in this House. For in the most part they have been brought in here in a sudden death sort of way. As the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) has just explained, there are five Proposals before us-Nos 8, 9, 10, 11 and 12. On this occasion at the opening of a new session of Parliament it is possible to make an informed guess as to the nature of some of the Proposals-Nos 8, 9 and 10. on As we have seen, those Proposals were gazetted we were in recess and, of course, under the rules they had to be brought to the Parliament within four or five days of the commencement of the session. There is no need to go over the Minister's speech in detail, but Proposals No.8 applies to the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendations on textiles, clothing and footwear; Proposals No.9 implements a decision in relation to the report of the lAC on lamps and light fittings as they relate to developing country preference; and Proposals No. 10, which was gazetted on 15 July, relates to an administrative change in relation to certain disposable shopping bags of artificial plastic material. Copies of the IA- reports have been available since the days when those decisions were. gazetted. It was possible for those who take an intelligent interest in this subject to do a little homework in those cases; there has been some time to think. But the first the House heard of the other two Proposals, Nos 11 and 12, was in the Minister's speech today and there has been Â·no time to give them consideration. Mr MooreYou are supposed.to be adjourning the debate, aren't you?

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: TARIFF PROPOSALS
text: I say with a certain amount of annoyance that the Minister sought to interject on me. Of course, the adjournment of the debate is what normally happens in these circumstances. But when is there an opportunity to debate these matters? The processes of this House have gone from bad to worse. In fact the only opportunities to debate these matters are in Customs Tariff Validation Bill debates when all of these proposals are brought back and legislated for, In the past we at least have had those Customs Tariff Validation Bill debates twice a year. We have had them at the end of this session-say, early December-and then at the end of the autumn session-say, late Mayor early June. But the horse has bolted by the time we come to debate the Customs Validation Bill. All the things that have been gazetted or brought to this House in the way or proposals are then a fait accompli. The matters have rested for all those months in the meantime. Let us face facts-those Customs Tariff Validation Bill debates are nothing more than farces and opportunities for one orÂ· two to ride a hobbyhorse in relation to Customs matters; and nobody takes any notice of them. I might say that on each of those occasions I have sought to persuade the Government to change the procedures by which these matters are dealt with in the Parliament. I have moved amendments. Let me read one of them: That all words after That' be omitted with a view to tuting the following words: Whilst not opposing the BillThe Customs Tariff Validation BillThe House is of the opinion that a Parliamentary Standing Committee. on Tariffs and Excis.e Â·should be established. to examine each change in tariffs and excise following the gazettal of proposals or their being introduced into the Pa.r1iament on the one hand and before related Bills are introduced into the House on the other hand. Of course, that is what ought to take placei! we are serious about the people's representatives having a say in the government of this country and if such matters are not to be determined by executive action. That is what is being done in this case-it is being done by executive action and the Parliament is being allowed only a certain tokenism when it comes to. discussing these matters. However, on this occasion I got up on the spur of the moment not only to say these things but also to say something about the particular Proposals . .In terms of the first three, about which I have had time to do some study, I can say that the lAC found that no lasting harm was being occasioned, for instance, by the developing country preference .. The Government accepted that advice and, in the absence of any submissions from those affected being made to me or to other members of the Opposition, who have not passed any submissions on t9 me, so do we on this side of the House accept those Proposals. But, I repeat, they are the exception. It is only at the beginning of each session that we have had any time to look at these Proposals as they have beenÂ· gazetted a little earlier. Most often, the items are introduced in a sudden death way, as Proposals II and 12 have been introduced on this occasion. . I had to make a decision as the Minister spoke as to what I should do on this occasion. Frankly, from what he has said, I am unable to say one way or the other whether the Opposition accepts or rejects the particular matters put forward. On this occasion, if my ears served me correctly and I heardÂ· what the Minister had to say a few moments ago, the Government has not accepted the recommendation of those who have looked at this matter in depth. The Government may indeed be correct. I am glad that it has exercised its separate judgment on the case, but I cannot exercise a separate judgment. I have not even had the time or the opportunity to look at the lAC report on the subject, because I did not get.it until a short time ago when the reports were presented in this chamber. What an absurd way to do business. As I have said, the procedures have gone from bad to worse. substi- I am not sure that I explained fully earlier that previously at least we had these Customs Tariff Validation Bills before us twice a year, but now the Government has changed this procedure and we are going to have Customs Tariff Validation Bills before us only once a year. Probably in this case the Parliament will next be able to debate and make known any individual opinions on Proposals II and 12, which it has only just heard about, in about next Mayor June which is probably when the validation Bill will be introduced. I am not sure about that-perhaps the Government will introduce it once a year in Decemberbut I suspect that it will be in next Mayor June when we see these miscellaneous transport, equipment and other proposals that have been brought to the'House today. I repeat that previous Ministers for Business and Consumer Affairs promised me that they would view very sympathetically the idea of improving procedures. I regret that as much as I enjoy the company and appreciate the person of the present Minister, on a professional basis I have to say that he has gone from bad to worse in this matter and that he is not improving things. I think he was the one responsible for the Customs Tariff Validation Bills now coming in only once a year rather than twice a year. Mr Moore-But you have said that the debate is useless.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: TARIFF PROPOSALS
text: I am helped by another interjection ,from the Minister. Unfortunately, others will not have heard it; so I will repeat said that I have said that the debate is useless. I have said that the debate is useless in these circumstances because we have had no time to hear the Proposals. We know that in every other case relating to matters which come before this Parliament, a week's notice is given for the Opposition to receive representations from the people, to apply its own judgment and then to bring its views to this Parliament a week later. I think the Minister must be joking. I must admonish him for this because I believe that this is a very serious matter. The point is that the proper time for debate to take place is a week after such matters have been introduced. Six months later, the Proposals having been law for that time, is not the correct time for such a matter to be debated. Of course, in our view each ORe of the Government's decisions arising from each report of the Industries Assistance Commission should be the subject of all-party scrutiny. That is why we have suggested time and again the establishment of a parliamentary standing committee on customs and excise tariffs. I draw to the attention of the House the fact that we all have conceded on some occasion the benefits of all-party committee work on these sorts of subjects. We forget the point scoring when we are in a committee situation. We do not forget our ideology but we allow ourselves to be influenced by facts rather than just emotions when we are out of this chamber doing committee work. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts, amongst its other functions, looks in depth at the reports of the Auditor-General. It looks also at departmental estimating, Similarly, a parliamentary standing committee of this sort should be looking in depth at the work of the lAC. I would accept, with a great deal of interest, any submission that was put to me that the scope of this standing committee could be widened beyond just looking at proposals in relation to customs and excise tariffs. Perhaps it would be the body that looked not only at the work of the lAC in depth but also at the work of the Trade Practices Commission and the various reports it brought down. We might give the body a separate name if it did that, but it may well be the correct standing committee of the Parliament to look at that sort of work. It is tremendously important to the government of this country that greater interest be taken by parliamentarians in the work of statutory bodies such as the lAC. As soon as the Australian Labor Party takes over the national government of this country after the very next election, we will be reestablishing the Prices Justification Tribunal. I would once again listen very carefully and with it. He interest to submissions that such a committee should look at the detailed work and reports of the Prices Justification Tribunal as well. Mr Deputy Speaker, an occasion such as this-one of those rare occasions when tariff proposals are debated immediately-raises the whole subject of tariffs and protection in this country. I will not labour the point but will spend just a couple more minutes to draw to your attention and to the attention of the House the considerable confusion that exists as to what is happening on the tariff front at present. I am indebted to some work by Mr Rob Chalmers in a weekly newsletter that he puts out entitled Inside Canberra. He states that many of the officials in government believe that the events which led to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) stating that there was to be a general inquiry into the levels of tariffs in this country were: . . . not exactly handled in the best traditions of the Westminster system. Mr Chalmers went on: In other words, some officials who should have been consulted were not. It is assumed that there will be some sort of interdepartmental committee formed to draw up the reference to the Industries Assistance Commission for the six months inquiry into lower protection mentioned by Mr Fraser on Wednesday night. 1 think it was Wednesday, 5 August. Mr Chalmers may have been the first to draw attention to these facts, but just what is going on in this matter of general inquiry of the lAC into tariffs is now the subject of a great deal of speculation in the Press and informed circles in this country generally. I say on behalf of the community that I hope the Government took a decision at its Cabinet meeting today. I see the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) sitting in the House. He can give me some information by saying whether or not a Government announcement on this subject is coming forward today. Can he nod his head and say yes?

Title: TARIFF PROPOSALS
text: I shall certainly speak through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and say that there is a tragedy for this country at present in the enormous uncertainty that exists in industry relating to the Government's policy on matters of protection. There is a hiatus in the motor vehicle industry and in industry generally. While these general inquiries are about and while there is uncertainty in the Government-it cannot make up its mind on the general terms of reference-investment decisions are put off. While investment decisions are postponed new jobs are not created. All of this is happening at a time when the hidden unemployed are taken into consideration, as they should be. Half a million people are unemployed in this country. There is an expectation that things are getting worse, not better. Inflation and unemployment are on the rise and interest rates, as we have just heard from a previous debate-as if we did not know it already-are at unprecedented levels. I ask for some certainty in these areas and some decisions and announcements from the Government on these tariff matters. I was quoting earlier from Mr Chalmers newsletter of 10 days ago. In the last two or three days he has brought out another one. There has been even more in this morning's Australian Financial Review relating to this uncertainty; We learn that industry awaits with great interest just what will emerge from Mr Fraser's statement that the Industries Assistance Commission will be asked to the take into account 'recent Government decisions'. In this general inquiry which is to take six months we do not know whether the motor vehicle industry will be back in the melting pot or whether it will be excluded because of the decisions which are due to be taken now on the work that the Industries Assistance Commission is doing into the motor vehicle industry. What about textiles, clothing and footwear? Did we not have announcements at the end of last year relating to policy decisions which were supposed to last seven years? What sort of uncertainty now is created in those particular industries? Will they be included? Another factor in the uncertainty is that we just do not know. I repeat that while this 'do not know' era continues, investment decisions are postponed. In summary, I ask the Government to improve its standards in many respects, but in relation to these matters there are two particular aspects for consideration. First of all, will the Government get off its tail and make sure that we have better procedures in this Parliament for dealing with the particular tariff proposals it brings before us? Secondly, will it get off its tail and announce to this country what it has in mind in relation to the protection of industry and to the inquiry that has been announced? Will the inquiry last six months? Will we have another six months of uncertainty while investment decisions are postponed? What are the particular terms of reference? I rest my case there. NA NA
