Question resolved in the affirmative. FREEDOM OF INFORMATION BILL 1981 Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

Speaker: Mr VINER
Title: DISCHARGE OF TARIFF PROPOSALS
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The Freedom of Information Bill represents a major initiative by the Government in its program of administrative law reform. It is, in many respects, a unique initiative. Although a number of countries have freedom of information legislation, Australia was the first country in which a Westminster-style government brought forward such a measure. We have now been joined by Canada and New Zealand. This Bill will establish for members of the public legally enforceable rights of access to information in documentary form held by Ministers and government agencies except where an overriding interest may require confidentiality to be maintained. The basic principles of the Freedom of Information Bill are simple. Firstly, government departments and authorities should make their structures and functions known to the public and publish the rules and guidelines they apply in making decisions affecting members of the public. Secondly, members of the public are entitled to access to documents held by government departments and authorities unless there are special reasons for not making those documents public. These principles are emphasised in clause 3 of the Bill which sets out the object of the legislaJion. That clause also contains an expression of parliamentary intention as to the manner in which the legislation should be interpreted. The discretions conferred by the Bill are to be exercised. 'as far as possible to facilitate andÂ· promote, promptly and at the lowest reasonable cost, the disclosure of information'. Such a right of access cannot, of course, be absolute. Complete openness of government is not possible. For some purposes, confidentiality is essential. It is widely recognised that governments, like individuals, families and business organisations, cannot operate effectively without a certain amount of privacy. The crucial element in drafting the Freedom of Information Bill has been to strike the appropriate balance between openness and confidentiality. The Freedom of Information Bill has been the subject of an extensive public and parliamentary part debate. The Bill is based upon the report of an inter-departmental committee, which was - abled in the Parliament in November 1976. The first BilJ was introduced into the Senate by the Attorney General on 9 June 1978. It was referred by the Senate to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. After an extensive inquiry, that Committee presented its report to the Senate in November 1979. The Committee Second Reading recommended a number of substantial changes to the Bill. The Government's response to the Senate Committee's report was tabled in the Senate by the Attorney-General in September 1980. A further Bill was introduced into the Senate in the autumn sittings this year. That Bill comes to this House after a number of significant amendments were made during the proceedings in the Senate. Much of debate about the Bill has focused on two matters. These are, first, the appropriate balance between openness and confidentiality and, secondly, the extent to which the right of access to information given by the Bill should require the commitment of resources in departments and authorities at a time when the Government is seeking to contain the size of the public sector. Whilst the Government believes that the Bill as it now stands goes as far as practicable at present, the Government has expressed the view that it would be appropriate for the legislation to be reviewed after it has been in force for about three years. Furthermore, the Government has undertaken to review, after 12 months- operation, the question whether additional rights of access might be given to documents already in the possession of agencies at the date on which the Bill comes into operation, the so-called prior documents. The Bill establishes the general principle of openness. At the same time, it identifies and defines those circumstances in which confidentiality should be maintained. Thus the Bill contains provisions to protect personal privacy and confidential commercial information, vital national interests such as security and defence and the conduct of government activities for which confidentiality is essential. But even in these cases the Bill does not prohibit information being made available. The Bill emphasises that Ministers and agencies are free to make information available or to give access to documents in any case where this may properly be done. The policy of the Government is to make as much information as possible available to the pUblic; This was set out in a statement on access to official information made on behalf of the Government in the Senate by the Attorney-General on 9 June 1978. The Westminster system of government, as we know it, is distinguished by a particular relationship between the Executive government and the Parliament. The Executive Government of the day bears a responsibility to the Parliament and, through the Parliament, to the people, for the proper discharge of the government of the country. Care must therefore be taken in adapting to the Australian system of government legal concepts derived from countries having different systems of government. The proposals in each country must be considered in the context in which they are intended to operate. Thus, the present Bill must be viewed in the context of the systems of administrative review which have already been established by this Parliament, namely, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and the Federal Court of Australia operating under the powers conferred on it by the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. In addition, there are differences in the nature of the'parliamentary institutions in each country which affect the relationships between ministers and the Parliament. The Bill thus contains provisions necessary to recognise the particular features of Cabinet government and to give proper weight both to the function of Ministers to make decisions relating to fundamental issues of government for which they have ultimate responsibility and to the special relationship between Ministers and their senior officials. In this regard it is significant that Ministers are subject to questioning in Parliament on matters within their ministerial responsibility both without notice and upon notice by members of the Parliament. By second reading speeches on Bills, by their participation in debates, and by the making of ministerial statements Ministers also give much information about government activity directly to the Parliament. In addition, papers and reports are tabled in the Parliament and much informative material is published by the Australian Government Publishing Service. In addition, material is made available by departments and authorities, including the participation by departmental officers in seminars and conferences and the publication of annual reports. The Government has encouraged Ministers and departments to make as much information available to the public as possible, consistent with the requirements of necessary confidentiality. Existing laws under which information is required to be made available will not be affected by the Bill. These include the tabling in Parliament of reports by statutory authorities, the requirements to produce, subject to-public interest privilege, documents before courts and other tribunals, and the giving of evidence before parliamentary committees. In addition, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 entitles persons adversely affected by decisions of Ministers, officials and authorities to reasons for those decisions over a wide range of subject matters. The Freedom of Information Bill operates on a wider scope than any of the existing means of obtaining access to information. Access to information under the Bill will not depend on the person seeking access having to show a special interest in obtaining the information. Lack of a special interest will not be a ground on whiCh information can be withheld. The Bill provides for a legally enforceable right of access to documented information. This represents a radical change of approach. The Bill will require Ministers or departments seeking to withhold information to justify their decisions to deny access to information by reference to the criteria specified in the Bill. The Freedom of Information Bill, together with other recent reforms in administrative law, thus emphasises the administrative accountability of Ministers and their departments. In common with that legislation it remains within the concept of a 'Westminster-based' system of government, but forms part of an improved system of judicial and public scrutiny of decison-making processes within the Government. So far I have referred to those aspects of the Bill which preserve a proper balance of interest in providing for mandatory access to information. There is, however, another aspect of the concept of open government embodied in the Bill. The Bill imposes a positive obligation on departments and authorities to make public their organisations and structure, and the functions they perform. They are also obliged to make available to their 'clients' the criteria employed in the exercise of decision making functions, by making available for inspection and purchase copies of manuals, guidelines, instuctions and the like. Some of this material is now available, but not in a co-ordinated form, nor is it easy for a member of the public to find it out. The Administrative Arrangements Order specifies the functions of departments in broad terms and some details of organisation and structure are given in the Commonwealth Government Directory. Some departments have published manuals and the like for the information of those interested, but others have not. The relevant provisions are corttained in Part II of the Bill. Parts III, IV and VI of the Bill are concerned with the right of a person to obtain access to a document in the possession of a Minister, a department or authority. They are based on the principle, as set out in clause 11, that every person has a legally enforceable right to obtain access in accordance with the Act to such documents unless the document concerned is an exempt document. These Parts of the Bill do not, however, provide for access to documents which will be available under archives legislation, to documents open to public access in accordance with other statutory provisions, to documents published for sale to the public or, with certain exceptions, to existing documents already in the possession of agencies when the legislation comes into force. Two of these exclusions require some explanation. The archives Bill, which is before the Senate, will regulate the archival collections of the Commonwealth and will deal in that context with rights of access to documents more than 30 years old. Different principles apply to documents that do not directly concern current events and where the requirements of confidentiality are not the same. The other point concerns priordocuments. To give a general right to access to all existrequires ing documents, as well as to those brought into existence in the future, would substantially increase the. administrative burden and cost of implementing the legislation at a time when the Government is seeking to contain the resources devoted to the Public Service. There are, however, two exceptions to the general exclusion of prior documents. The first, and most significant, concerns the case where a person seeks access to a document which contains information relating to his personal affairs. In that case, his right of access under the Bill extends to documents which came into the possession of an agency up to five years prior to the commencement of Part III of the Bill. The second exception deals with the case where access to a prior document is reasonably necessary to a proper understanding of a document to which the applicant has lawfully had access, whether under the freedom of information legislation or otherwise. The right of access given by the Bill extends to such a prior document. Moreover, of course, in keeping with the general principle that the Bill does not constitute a complete code of access, prior documents may be made available where this can lawfully be done. The grounds of exemption on which access to a document may be refused are set out in Part IV of the Bill. I shall explain the principles which have been adopted in drafting these exemptions. As I have said, the Bill provides a balance between the public interest served by access to information against the public interest in maintaining the confidentiality necessary for the operation of government and the protection of the commercial confidences and the privacy of those who have dealings with government or about whom information is collected by government. The clauses of the Bill defining the exempt categories of documents are drafted for the most part in terms of the interest, whether the public interest or the interest of individuals or private sector bodies, which may be damaged by disclosure of the documents in question. Only in some cases are the exempt documents defined by reference to the nature of the document itself, such as Cabinet and Executive Council documents. It is of the essence of Cabinet government that the deliberations of Cabinet and of the Executive Council should be protected from mandatory "disclosure. Of course, the tenor of many Cabinet decisions, as well as various Executive Council decisions are published. The documents which make these decisions public are not, of course, exempt documents under the Bill. Except in those cases where a document is in an exempt category by reason of its nature, the Bill. a decision to refuse access' to a document to be made on the basis of an assessment whether harm would result from the document being made public. Thus, for example, a document is not exempt because it relates to Commonwealth State matters; it is exempt only if its disclosure under the Act could reasonably be expected to cause damage to Commonwealth-State relations. A document is not exempt merely because it relates to the internal working of a department; to justify refusal, disclosure must cause some detriment to a specified public interest, such as prejudice to the public interest in maintaining the full and frank discussion of issues between officers or the preservations of confidential relations between Ministers and officials. By drafting the Bill in this way, it is intended to emphasise the need to justify any denial of access by reference to an interest that should, in the particular case, be preferred to the public interest in access to the information in the document. Moreover, where only part of the matter contained in a document is such as to justify a denial of access, the Bill would impose a positive obligation to make a copy of the remainder of the document available if it is practicable to segregate the exempt matter and the segregation does not result in a misleading document. In enacting freedom of information legislation within a Westminster-based system of government, the matter of the final authority to decide whether the giving of access would be contrary to the public interest is clearly of fundamental importance. It would be inconsistent with the responsibility of Ministers to the Parliament for the proper conduct of government that final decisions on the public release of documents damaging to vital public interests should be in the hands of bunals not accountable to the Parliament. Whilst the Bill provides for an independent review' of all decisions to refuse access to the document, there are certain cases in which a decision by the reviewing tribunal that a document is not an exempt document and therefore access should be given does not take effect without the concurrence of the responsible Minister. These cases concern matters relating to defence, national security, international relations and Commonwealth-State relations, the protection of Cabinet and Executive Council confidentiality and the relations between Ministers and their official advisers where disclosure would be contrary to the public interest. In these cases, the Bill vides for a system of conclusive certificates. Such a certificate establishes that a document in respect of which it is given is an exempt document. In the case of Cabinet and Executive Council documents, such a certificate may be given by the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet or the Secretary to the Federal Executive Council, as the case may be. In other cases, the certificate may be given by the responsible Minister or the principal officer of the agency concerned. The Bill establishes ,a special judicial tribunal, the Document Review Tribunal, for the purposes of reviewing a case in which such a certificate is given. The function of the Document Review Tribunal is to consider whether there are reasonable grounds for the' claim that the document concerned is exempt, and to recommend accordingly. If the Tribunal considers that there are no reasonable grounds for. claiming exemption in respect of a particular document, the conclusive certificate nevertheless still operates unless the responsible Minister decides to revoke it. In all other cases, the question whether a document is in an exempt category and therefore access may be refused may be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which is empowered to make a final decision on the matter subject only to appeal to the Federal Court of Australia on questions oflaw. The class of documents that have come to be described as internal working documents is a particularly important class of documents. These are defined in clause 36 of the Bill. They are the documents that are concerned with the deliberative and policy-forming processes of government. It is well recognised that it would be prejudicial to the free and frank exchange of opinion for many documents of this kind, particularly those at the more senior levels of government, to become publicly available as a matter of course. The neutrality of Public Service advisers, and the ability of tri- governments of differing political complexions to have confidence in the impartiality of advice given by their Public Service advisers, would be damaged if officials became identified with particular advice whether or not that advice was accepted by the Ministers to whom it was given. The class of documents specified in clause 36 is, however, a wide class, necessarily so in order to cover many diverse situations, and it is apparent that the disclosure of many documents falling within that class might not be prejudicial to the public interest. Clause 36 therefore provides that an internal working document may not be withheld unless its release would be contrary to the propublic interest on a particular ground to be specified by the agency when refusing access. The protection of business confidentiality has been a matter of particular concern in the drafting of the legislation. Government agencies come into the possession of a great deal of information of a confidential commercial character, much of it supplied on a voluntary basis. A number of private sector organisations have expressed concern at the possibility of disclosure to competitors of information supplied by commercial enterprises. Ministers have given assurances that confidential information of a commercial character supplied by private sector organisations would not be subject to disclosure under freedom of information legislation. Clause 43 of the Bill therefore exempts from mandatory disclosure information of a confidential commercial character. The Bill also requires an agency to consult with the supplier of information of this kind and to take into account any submissions the supplier makes before deciding to release a document containing the information. Furthermore, the supplier is given the right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against the release of such a document on the ground that the information in it would be exempt under clause 43. Matters of personal privacy are protected by clause 41 of the Bill, which provides that access to a document may be refused, other than to the person involved, if disclosure of it would be an unreasonable disclosure of the personal affairs of any person. Clause 41 is to be regarded as an interim solution to this matter, pending consideration of the report on privacy to be made by the Australian Law Reform Commission. When that report is available, the Government will review the provisions of clause 41. Most of the remaining exemptions in Part IV are concerned with the protection of the national economy, of particular operation and interests of agencies and of law enforcement and public safety. Special provision is made for the protection of documents relating to the administration of State company and securities law under the Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme. Clause 38 of the Bill is intended to have the effect of preserving the. operation of special secrecy provisions in other legislation. The visions Government has, however, given an undertaking that all existing secrecy provisions will be reviewed within three years of the freedom of formation legislation coming into force. Where only part of a document contains exempt there is an obligation to make available a copy of the document with the exempt matter deleted, if it is practicable to do so and the deletions would not produce a misleading result. This is provided cipal by clause 22 of the Bill. Moreover, in those where the Bill provides for a certificate to be clusive of the fact that a document is an exempt document and only a part of the document tains exempt matter, the certificate must identify that part. I now turn to the agencies to which the Bill applies. Broadly speaking, it applies to all Comapplicant monwealth departments, to Commonwealth agency statutory authorities and the holders of statutory offices, and to the registries of courts and tri-Â· bunals. Provision is made for non-statutory bodies established by the Commonwealth, incorporated companies or associations under the control of Commonwealth and the holders of non-statutory appointments to be brought within the scope of the Bill by regulations. The Bill does not apply the parliamentary departments or to the agencies specified in Part I of the second Schedule to Bill. A number of agencies are exempt in respect of specified functions. These are set out in Part of the second Schedule. The procedures for obtaining Bill involve a minimum of formality; The Bill requires that a decision on a request for access given as soon as practicable and in any event more than 60 days after the request is received. The time limit applies to a request that is identified as being made under the Freedom of Information Act and that is sent to the agency concerned at an address of the agency specified in the regulations. If such a request is not dealth with within the 60-day period, the applicant will be entitled to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as if his requests has been denied. The period of 60 days may be reduced by regulation if experience shows that agencies are able to deal with requests within a shorter time without undue strain on resources. I do not propose to describe in detail the procedural provisions in Part III of the Bill. I refer only to two important aspects. Firstly, there is a statutory duty on agencies to assist applicants to make requests in a form which will enable them to be dealt with under the Bill. This is a significant feature of the Bill. Secondly, a number of the prohave regard to the resource implications of requests, particularly requests which would involve searching for and collating a large number inof documents, by empowering an agency to refuse a request if the work involved would substantially matter, interfere with its other operations. The Bill provides for extensive rights of review of decisions refusing access. Where the initial decision is made at a level below ministerial or prinofficer level, the first step in the review is for cases an application to be made to the agency conconcerned to have the decision reviewed. Alternatively, a complaint might be made to the Ombudsconman, who has his ordinary powers of investigation. In addition, the Bill provides that the Ombudsman is not precluded from investigating a matter on the ground that the Bill provides for an alternative means of review. If the is .dissatisfied with the decisionÂ· of the on internal review, there is a right of appeal in all cases to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. However, as already noted, there are certain decisions affecting the more sensitive classes of documents which' may not be reviewed the by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Bill provides that these decisions may be reviewed by a new tribunal, constituted under Part VII of the to Bill, to be known as the Document Review Tribunal. The decisions of the Administrative the Appeals Tribunal have binding force. Those of the Document Review Tribunal are, as already II noted, of a recommendatory nature only but, being given in public, will necessarily carry a great access under the deal of weight. Part V of the Bill. provides for amendment of be personal records. A person who obtains access not under the Bill toa document containing information relating to his personal affairs may, if he believes that information to be incomplete, inaccurate, misleading or out of date, apply to the agency concerned to have the necessary corrections or alterations made. There is a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if the agency concerned refuses to make the requested correction or alteration. This right of correction of personal records applies only to Australian citizens and persons having permanent resident status in Australia. The provisions of Part V are regarded as interim pending the report of the Law Reform Commission on privacy. The Government believes that the Bill represents a major step forward in removing unnecessary secrecy from the administrative processes of government. Together with the legislation already on the statute book, the Bill will vance the Government's intention to make Commonwealth administration more responsive to the public need. I commend the Bill to the House. Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith. MR LIONEL BOWEN (Kingsford-Smith) (5.13)-The matter we are debating-it is very significant; we have an immediate debate-is the Freedom of Information Bill 1981. Of course, it should not cause any surprise that we are to debate the matter immediately. It has been before the Senate for some years. It follows, as I understood the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) said, that it would be expected that we would have some knowledge of that matter. We have. I say on behalf of the Opposition that we are not opposing the second reading of the Bill. As the Bill has been before a Senate committee we will be moving amendments in the committee stage which will be in accordance with the recommendations of that committee. The Freedom of Information Bill comes to this House after being in the Senate for some considerable period. It seems to have come with a rush into this House. It would appear that the Senate felt obliged finally to conclude its debate on this Bill before the Government lost control of the Senate. I do not know what the sudden urgency is now because obviously there was no urgency in the Senate where the Bill has been for some years until the concluding stages of the last session as I said. It has become very apparent that we ought to be debating this legislation. In fact, as I understand it, that is all we will be debating this week because the Government regards it as having such a high priority. We say at the outset that amendments have been accepted in the Senate. They have been of some value. Some of them have been actually accepted by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in a fashion, if I may say so, that would indicate that he has accepted them in the spirit of improving the Bill though I think possibly against the wishes of his Government. To that extent one must congratulate the Attorney General. But we do not want to overstate the case. There is much that can be done and should have been done and, in fact, should have bee'n accepted by the Senate in the light of the recommendations of its committee. As I say, there has been improvement but there still remains much to be done. The, original Bill was aptly described as a Bill that was concerned with freedom from information. There was no chance at all to say that we could have obtained any information under the original legisad- lation. As a result of the issue going to a Senate committee the Bill has been marginally improved. If we look at the Bill from the point of view of assessing its merits, in any marking it would get about five out of IO-barely a pass. The Bill is not as good as it could have been or should have been. However, it is not as obnoxious as it was in its initial stages. I place on record again that Senator Durack has faced considerable difficulties. I am convinced that had he had his own way the Bill would have been much better in its final form than it is now. However, the Attorney-General was overriden by a very dominant Cabinet with a most dominant Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) who appears to be obsessed with s'ecrecy. We will deal with these matters as we go through some of the amendments later in the week. We have seen the Government somewhat obsessed with secrecy. The most ludicrous example was the attempt to suppress the publication of the Munster and Walsh publication in what were called the Australian defence papers between 1969 and 1975. It was well known that these papers were known to many other agencies. In fact, some of them had already been circulated. The Government took the extraordinary provision of going to the High Court of Australia to say that those matters should not be published. We should bear in mind, of course, that the book had already been published. Mr Justice Mason in the High Court accurately pinpointed the fallacies in this unjustified attitude to secrecy. But the same attitude underlies this Bill. There 'is this extraordinary belief that information is a gift given only to a government, that the Government owns the information and that the public should be grateful if it gets any information at all. We on the Opposition side believe that freedom of information is a basic democratic' right and it lies at the very heart of the democratic system. If people are to make informed choices about a particular matter or a policy or about who is to govern this country, then the widest possible information should be made available in order that the choices can be made in an informed manner. Withholding of information should be kept to the barest minimum. In order to protect the public interest we must always guarantee that there will be an impartial body, such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, that can certainly guarantee that protection. The withholding of information goes beyond simply leaving the public in the dark; it can be used positively to mislead the public, as occurred with circumstances surrounding our entry and our commitment to the Vietnam war. subsequent publications have been able to illustrate clearly that there was a complete deception of the Australian nation. The withholding of information has another effect. It makes Government information a valuable commodity. It makes insiders to the processes of government, that is people with special information, able I to use, that information to their advantage or, indeed, leak it or sell it at a profit. We have, for example, had debates in this Parliament on the difficulties in the tendering for computer facilities. Not the least of Which we can hark back to is the IBM Australia Ltd and Facom Australia Ltd disaster and the advantages which can be gained from having the ear of government, or, in that case, of the Prime Minister. It was very well known that IBM was given some assistance to get some reconsideration of a decision that was against it. But this was not known to anyone else at the time. Yet the Parliament and the Australian public were not, able to obtain that same information. In many of the answers to questions in, this place, whether they be questions 0)1 notice or questions without notice, it is clear that Ministers are not aware of the principles of freedom of information or, if they are, they are not prepared to bring into effect, by way of their answer:>, the tenor of those principles. There is a view that all of the faults of the Freedom of Information Bill have been caused by the bureaucrats fighting to get their way. To some extent that could be true. But we have to look at it In the total cOflcept of wha:t has happened and what we are aware of. All blame does not lie with the bureaucrats. We are aware that bureaucrats believe it is highly dangerous to inform the public' of what is occurring in government. It is even more 'dangerous' at times, they say, to allow Ministers actually, to administer their departments. But, of course, because of our ability in this place, we are able to guarantee at times that Ministers come and go, but as people know, bureaucrats have a tendency to live on. The bureaucracy must take a lot of the blame for the delays in achieving freedom of information and for the fact that the principles of freedom of information have not been translated into legislation. It seems extraordinary that Ministers have used the argument put forward by the bureaucracy that the Westminster system is not compatible with comprehensive freedom of information legislation. That is completely incorrect. The Westminster system is largely a myth in Australia particularly under conservative governments. Ministers do not resign because of maladministration; they are not really accountable to Parliament and they do not take full responsibility for their departments. Time and again we have seen examples of Ministers being snowed by their departments and getting into serious political trouble. However, while there is no doubt that the bureaucracy does not want adequate freedom of information legislation, there are some exceptions. There is also no doubt that many Ministers,' including the Prime Minister (MrMa1colm Fraser) are very wary of allowing the public to know much at all. Too much government secrecy leads to ,a situation where leaks become the order of the day in informing the public. We can state without qualification that leaking is a reprehensible practice and one that often leads to misinformation, depending on, the motives of the person doing the leaking. Oppositions, of course, tend to have less strong views on leaking than when they are in government. Prior to 11 November 1975, the Prime Minister even invented a new theory which might be described as 'a duty to leak'. That new notion was so absurd that it took only until the relevant date-that is, 11 November 1975before the Prime Minister discarded that theory and adopted the view that public servants who leaked, contrary to the interests of the Government, should be disciplined by firing squads. Prime Ministers, of course,do not leak to the Press; they merely give background briefings. These background briefings are sometimes regarded by State Premiers in much the same way as the Prime Minister regards leaks by public servants. The reason for freedom of information legislation is to give the public a legal right to information held by Ministers and government agencies. The exceptions to this right'must be kept to an absolute minimum. For example, there must be no constraint on the ability of Cabinet to have full and frank discussions. Freedom of information does not make people a party to what happens in the Cabinet room. The problem with this Bill is that the list of exemptions is far too wide. Many of the exemptions are too widely drafted and, in most cases-this is fundamental to what we are about-the decision of the Minister is final. One can advert to clauses 33 to 47 which are included in Part IV of the Bill. The trend of judicial opinion shown in Australia in cases such as the Sankey case and the case known as the Fairfax case is that it is the courts and not the Government which ought to decide whether the public has a right to information. If one takes the view that the public has a right to information, which can be excluded only in the most exceptional cases, it is quite wrong in principle to allow the Government, which may be an interesed party in the withholding of information, to be the final arbiter of whether disclosure will be allowed. There is provision in the Bill for the creation of the Document Review Tribunal. It can act as some mitigation of the position. But that does not alter the basic objection that the withholding of information can be finally decided by the Government. While one has s'ome respect for Senator Durack for deciding on the Document Review Tribunal 'model, one has no respectfor the Liberal senators who made so much noise about freedom of information but who' acquiesced in it. For Senator Durack it was a concession. For the Liberal senators it was a sellout. I make the point that we were given this recommendation by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs of which those senators were members. I note from the Senate Hansard that one senator spoke about the seven deadly sins when otJjecting to what the Bill meant. The first deadly sin nominated by the honourable gentleman was that relating to conclusive ministerial certificates. The honourable gentleman, with others, acquiesced to 'the relevant provision in the Bill. So if one is to be condemned to hell for practising the seven deadly sins, these senators should look aUheir careers in the future because certainly they did not vote in accordance with what they said, nor did they vote in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Committee. At least the Government knew that it could convince its own senators. The almost indecent haste with which the Bill was pushed through the Senate in the last session was in order that the Bill could be passed, as I said earlier, before the Government lost its Senate majority. We hear all kinds of nonsense about how Government senators treat their positions seriously in the so called House of Review. The proof of promises is performance. Government senators-in particular the three senators who I have mentionedwho are members of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs did not perform in respect of this Bill. Statements of intent and promises were made; they were not kept. The failure of the Senate to remove the use of conclusive ministerial certificates is an indictment of those sena tors. It places us in the House of Representatives again in the position of considering that perhaps at times we ought to have a few committees. If these senators could carryon a review over a period of years, as well meaning as it was, and be able to debate the Bill at such length and, to some extent, improve it, one must, in all humanity, suggest that if the House of Representatives could have this Bill before it for longer than a week, perhaps we could make some amendments. If we could have a committee of Government and Opposition members considering this Bill, surely we could make even more amendments than the worthy gentlemen in the other House were able to makeover a period of years. Many of the exemptions remain too wide. Clause 44, for example, dealing with documents affecting the national economy, is a nonsense provision. Paragraph (1) (a) declares documents exempt if disclosure could reasonably be expected to have a substantial effect on the ability of the Government of the Commonwealth to manage the economy of Australia. The simple answer to this, I suppose, is that no document can be exempt on this ground because the Government has no ability to manage the economy of Australia. However, this simply demonstrates how absurd it is to put such a criterion into legislation: If the exemption related to adverse effects on the economy of Australia-that is, not of the Government-it would at least be explicable. In its present form it is ludicrous. Paragraph (1) (b) of clause 44 is either a confidence trick or a piece of careless drafting. It exempts any document which could reasonably be expected to cause undue disturbance to business or an undue benefit or detriment to anyone because of a premature disclosure of proposed Government action or inaction. Surely there ought to be some limit on that sort of criteria. This clause is in no way confined to documents containing material of an economic nature, so it covers the whole field. If the Government were to accept one amendment in this place, it ought to accept our amen'dment to this clause, which is to redefine that provision and to guarantee that it relates to the question of the economy; otherwise the provision is so wide that the Government's bona fides must come into question. We also object to clause 33, not simply because of the use of conclusive certificates by Ministers, but also because there is a reference to Commonwealth-State relations which are put on the same basis a- international relations. Information communicated by any government, whether it be a State government or a government of another country, is automatically exempt. State governments will be aware of the possibilities here. All communications with the Commonwealth and information supplied to the Commonwealth will simply be stamped 'Confidential' and 'In Confidence'. That will be enough to exempt that document completely from disclosure. We propose an amendment to provide that disclosure must be contrary to the public interest-that is to ensure a test: Whether a document is contrary to the public interest-before it is exempt and to allow for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on a refusal to grant access. We would also like to see a provision for reverse freedom of information as it is called whereby a State government can appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of the decision that a document is not exempt. If it is good enough for the Commonwealth, why is it not good enough for a State? As far as Cabinet documents are concerned, there is at present no definition as to what exactly is meant by the term 'Cabinet documents'. It would appear that the term will embrace documents containing only factual material, technical reports, or reports prepared by outside consultants or statutory bodies. They ought not to be excluded on the grounds that they have been Cabinet documents or have been submitted to Cabinet or to the Executive Council. The provisions relating to other legislation taining secrecy provisions effectively mean that any such legislation is given an overriding force over the Freedom of Information Act. A list of . such legislation was provided to the Senate Select Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs by the Attorney-General's Department on 5 June 1979. It is Appendix 6 to the report, pages 485 489 inclusive. At the very least a full-scale review of this legislation should be made in order ascertain whether these provisions in other Acts conform to the principles of freedom of inforbe mation. If honourable members look at that list, they will see that it is very substantial indeed. Schedule to this Bill ought also to contain proanswer visions relating to freedom of information, that relating to secrecy provisions, in such a fashion that all such information is contained in the one piece of legislation. It should not be spread over the place so that one has to look at Commonwealth statutes, statutory rules, Australian Capi" tal Territory legislation, and at various bits and pieces of imperial legislation such as that applying to the Navy, Army and Air Force. It is.quite an extraordinary way to draft these provisions. One of the objections generally concerning Part IV of the Bill is that, apart from clause 36 dealing with internal 'Yorking documents, the concept of public interest is not consistently adopted as a sep. arate criterion. It is quite illogical to adopt a public interest test as a separate test for internal working documents, and then to exclude it as a test, for example, for financial or property interests of an agency-that is, clause 39-or documents relating to agency operations such as tests 'and audits, or personnel considerations or industrial relations negotiations, for example, clause 40. Clause 43 relating to trade secrets and business information is also too wide. Paragraph (1) (b) exempts information of which disclosure could diminish commercial value. There is no test whether disclosure would. be reasonable or whether the disadvantage that .the person would suffer would be unreasonable. Further, it relates to all businesses, whether lawful or unlawful. Ifa business were unlawful-for example, a business which was in breach of Commonwealth export controls or currency regulations, or Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines-one would have thought that it was necessarily in the public interest that this should be disclosed as should information concerning any illegal business whether it be gambling, prostitution or anything else. We also have strong objections to Schedule 2 which exempts certain agencies from the operation of the Bill either generally-that is Part conI-or in respect of particular categories of documents as found in Part II. While these agencies themselves. fall into different categories, particularly defence and commercial categories, it is the view of the Opposition that there is no justificatoin for exempting any agencies at all under Schedule 2. One might, of course, say that the to Commonwealth Bank should not be subject to the Freedom of Information Act in such a way that it to would be exposed to commercial disadvantage from its private bank competitors, or that it would against the interests of national security for the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to The be open to public scrutiny under the Act. The to such suggestions is that the Bill provides is, exemption for categories of documents such as business affairs and national security. In that respect, I refer to clauses 33 and 43, for example. It all is simply not necessary to exempt agencies in total. One would not think that very much information would be provided by ASIO. Nevertheless, any information provided by that agency under the Act will be a considerable improvement. In matters relating to procedure the Bill is also defective. In the area of documents in existence before the commencement of the Act, the Opposition in the Senate moved, as we propose to do again in the course of this debate, that all documents relating to the personal affairs of a person should be disclosed as should documents not more than five years old after the Act has been in operation for 12 months. The Government, in what appears to be ,a nice piece of sleight of hand, moved that documents relating to personal affairs could be obtained under the Act if they were not m<;>re than ,five years' old., This is very different from the Opposition proposal which was that all documents relating to personal affairs, irrespective of time, should be included within the ambit of the Act and that, after the Act has been in operation for a year, there should be retrospectivity for five years from the commencement of the Act. While the Opposition is pleased with the insertion of Part V which enables people to have their personal records amended, that right is contingent upon the person being able to obtain access to the documents. Under the Bill there is no right of access to documents which are more than five years old: Again I make the point that there is a great need to look at what happens from the point of view of access to documents. We have had privilege committees of this Parliament investigate many matters and, during the most recent and most famous inquiry, it was very clear that if the Parliament or the members of it had had access to the documents relating to' a person they would have seen that that person in fact appeared to have suffered an injustice. A recommendation has been made to this Parliament that there should be protection of witnesses legislation that ensures that anybody who appears before a parliamentary committee and gives evidence will not suffer damage or retribution in any way. There was strong prima facie evidence that that had in fact happened in the past and the only safety net for what had happened was the fact that this Parliament had a privileges committee. It might well be appropriate for us to have a standing committee to which any of our cOQstituents who feel there is some reason to have a-look at records may apply for that to happen. The records should be made ,available to that parliamentary committee to use its discretion as to what should be made available to the person concern-d. When the 'records were looked at, the most disquieting feature of the case that I have in mind, was not only that the person concerned might be prevented from getting information but also that the members of this Parliament, constituting a committee of the Parliament, were not to be given accurate information. If we cannot get the information and we have this sort of facility given to others to advise Ministers not to give that information, it will be very difficl,llt indeed for the public to have access to it. In other 'words, if something is wrong, incomplete, out-ofdate or misleading, it should not just be passed over. It does not become right simply because five years have passed. One of the arguments against retrospectivity is that it would cost too much to apply. This is an argument used by opponents of freedom of information. It was a cost argument which led to the adoption of the proposal for only five years' retrospectivity and ,then only after the Act has been in operation for one year. However, the cost argument can be easily overstated. The cost of the Freedom of Information Bill will be very small compared, for example, with the cost of' the Government's propaganda. The cost of retrospectivity for five years could be met easily by abolishing the Government Information Unit which is now, costing half a million dollars a yearsomething at which I think the Government ought to have a serious look. There are various other areas where the Act will be defective unless the Oppostition amendments are agreed to, and we are not 'always confident that they will be accepted. It is unfortunate that the Ombudsman has not been given the wide jurisdiction envisaged by the Committee and as moved for in the Senate by the Opposition. If honourable members look at the report of the Senate Select Committee, they will see that there was a role recommended for the Ombudsman. It was a question of being able to act as a counselor an advocate. It was also to guarantee that the ministerial decisions would be within the jurisidiction of the Ombudsman. None,of that has happened. It is unfortunate that the Government has not seen fit to adopt the proposal to reduce gradually the time limit for dealing with requests to 45 days after two years of operation of the Act and 30 days after four years of operation of the Act. It is now nine years since freedom of information became part of the Australian political agenda in the Labor Party's policy speech of 1972. Since then we have seen obstruction by the Public Service, particularly that manifested in the interdepartmental committee reports of 1974 and 1976. They could be described as proposals for freedom of information only by a misuse of the English language. There was no intention in those reports to give information. We saw the regretable. table 1978 Bill which led to the referral of the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on duct Constitutional and Legal Affairs. We saw a less than adequate response to that Committee's reand port from the government and the introduction of the 1981 Bill, which was only a slight improveformation ment on the 1978 Bill. A Bill has now been introduced into this House which at least adopts the first principles of freedom of information, only just. It ought to be our responsibility to prove that Bill. If we do not, we cannot say that we are concerned about the encroachment of the Executive-that includes both the Government and the Public Service-on the Parliament. The amendments which have been moved in the Senate will be moved again in this House. They are not being moved for the sake .of rhetoric or point scoring. We believe that all governments should pass legislation such as we have proposed. If it cannot be done by this Government it will done by a Labor Government. The Government ments rushed the legislation through the Senate during the last session. It said that it had gOne so far and would go no further. That is still not far enough. Senator Missen said atÂ· one stage that it was last opportunity to do something for the Bill. said that before he voted the wrong way. Howthe ever, he made the point that it is not good enough to pass a weak Bill and hoped that we will be able to improve it in 10 years' time. That is the present position. I hope that. the Government takes notice of what I have said. It is well aware of the ation because of the length of the Senate debate. The Opposition will move the amendments which I have foreshadowed.

Speaker: Mr HARRIS
Title: DISCHARGE OF TARIFF PROPOSALS
text: 1 welcome cies the Freedom of Information Bill. It has been a pursuant long time in the making. The Minister for Indusif trial Relations (Mr Viner), in his second reading speech, gave a history of this Bill. It has been fore the Senate and before various committees. has finally reached this House. The Deputy documents. Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) when sounded as though he would like to prolong its passage through this place. I think it is all to good to ensure that at long last we pass some freeOpposition dom of information Bill. The Bill is designed to give effect to the right know. It is a real step forward. It fundamentally affects the relationship between the Executive and the Parliament and between the citizen and the Government.Â· The right to information is essential in a democracy such as ours. If the tralian electorate is to be able to make a valid judgment on government policy it should have the greatest possible access to the information availHow can any community progress without a continuing and informed debate? How can it consuch a debate unless there is available to it in a formation on what action government is taking why it is taking in This Bill is designed to ensure that if someone wishes to have access to inheld by government it will not be unreasonably withheld. The object of the Bill is stated in clause 3. It can be summarised as being but to extend the right of the Australian community imto access to official information in the possession of the government Or the ComQlOnwealth by making available to the public information about the operations of departments and public authorities ensuing, in particular, that rules and practices affecting members of the public in their dealings with departments and public authorities are readily available.to persons affected by those rules and practices. Further, it is to create a general right of access to official information in documenbe tary form in the possession of Ministers, departand public authorities, limited only by what . is necessary to maintain essential confidentiality. Since the Bill was reintroduced into the Senate the this year a number of amendments have been He made. They go a long way towards dealing with alleged defects in the Bill. I refer in particular to the provisions regarding retrospectivity and what are known as conclusive certificates. The initial Bill was framed in a way which provided that no access to documents in existence at the date of situthe commencement of the Act could be obtained. This prohibition was not included for any sinister purpose. It was included for common sense, practical reasons. Nobody can yet be sure what the demand on Commonwealth departments and agenfor information will be once it is available to this Bill. It is not hard to imagine that there were no provisions limiting retrospectivity somebody might want information 10 or 15 years beof age. It would take some days, perhaps even It weeks, of searching to procure the appropriate Even if it were only a matter of days, one considers the cost of an - mployee of the Commonwealth, it is easy to appreciate that costs the could be considerable. The Deputy Leader of the said that the cost would .be less than the cost of the Government Information Unit. I to suggest that he would not have any idea of what the cost would be if there were a completely open access to all information held in government. The cost may be small or very large indeed. Until the Act has been in operation and we see the kinds of Ausdemands made upon the service that will be available, there is no sensible way of assessing the cost: It was for this reason that the Bill first prohibited access to information in existence prior to the date of commencement of the Act. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) stated that after three years there will be a in the light of the experience of those three years. The Minister for Industrial Relations, in his secretary ond reading speech, repeated that today. Howtificate ever, the Government has now changed its posticular ition to some extent. It has made an arrangement which I believe is reasonable pending that review. Certain documents will now be available even though they are already in existence. They are documents or parts of documents that contain inbilnal. formation relating to the personal affairs of a son where those documents become the official documents of an agency or a Minister not earlier than five years from the date of commencement of the Act. It also includes documents or parts of documents that are necessary to understand reasonably a document to which a person would otherwise be entitled to have access. It seems to me that these two amendments provide some proare tection for persons who are involved in or touched by a particular document already in existence also, quite sensibly, give access to documents which, were that access not provided,would renthe der incomprehensible documents which are already available. I repeat: The Attorney-General has reiterated on a number of occasions that there will be a review in the light of experience and the light of the demands made upon the Public Service once the Bill is passed. Should experience demonstrate a tolerable level of demand for circumstances. access to information, I would expect that a more relaxed approach could be taken and that a phased-in form of retrospectivity could take place. I notice that an amendment which moved in the Senate and which I gather will be moved here.by the Opposition later this week poses a form of phased-in access in that it is intended that the retrospectivity will not take place for a year after the commencement of the legislation. Quite clearly the Opposition itself alises that there may be some difficulties in the early stages of the operation of this legislation acknowledges that it cannot have any real knowla edge of what demands will be made upon the Pubpublic, lic Service to provide information. The area of conclusive certificates is another where there has been a significant amendment. both the Minister and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition have explained, there is a range of documents which at the moment, in pursuance of provisions of this legislation, cannot be provided to the public when it is stated that they are documents of a particular kind. They include docu-' ments affecting national security, defence, international relations and relations with States, has Cabinet documents, Executive Council docureview ments and internal working documents. It is intended that whenever a Minister, Cabinet secor Executive Council secretary signs a certo say that such documents are of a parcharacter, the documents will be exempt ,and the certificate will be conclusive of that fact. However, the Government accepted in the Senate a provision for a document review triThis tribunal will have the opportunity of perexamining documents, albeit very briefly in some cases, to ensure that they meet the description in that provision and, therefore, that they are genuinely documents covered by the exclusions set out in that provision. It is true that in those instances the findings of the review tribunal will be not mandatory but rather recommendatory. But when one considers the kinds of documents which involved and which are listed, it is clear that the tribunal's findings, though important, cannot be conclusive because in many instances presumand ably only the Ministers involved would know of the documents' ultimate significance. However, findings of the tribunal, though not mandatory, would be public and one would hope and expect that the Minister would not lightly ignore the findings. Indeed, one would expect, should a in tribunal make a finding that a doct::ment ought to be made public, that a Minister would be reluctant not to do so except in the most pressing There is one area where I think access is still overly limited. Clause 6 of the Bill provides for was j certain organisations to be exempt from the provisions of the legislation. The clause permits cerprotain organisations to be wholly exempt and permits other organisations, whilst not to be wholly exempt, at least to have certain of their documents exempted. It appears to me that a number reof organisations that are wholly exempt seem, at first sight at any event, to have no reasonable jusand tification for that exemption. One can understand variety of reasons for documents not being made including security reasons and the possibilityÂ· that commercial disadvantage may be suffered. But I refer to the second Schedule to the Bill. Part I lists the organisations or agencies which are wholly exempt. Part II lists the organisAs ations or agencies which are exempt in respect of particular documents. Part I includes the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Office of National Assessments. Let me make it quite clear that I am more than content for them to be exempt agencies. I do not suggest in any way that their documents should be open. For exampl-, ASIO is subject to a judicial audit and I believe that is sufficient protection for the public inter-st having regard to the kind of work it is required tei carry out. But in respect of some organisations listed in Part I of the second Schedule the explanation is less apparto the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission. Why that organisation should have all its documents exempt I frankly do not understand. No doubt it has commercial dealings. Perhaps they ought to be exempt in the sense that in Part II documents in respect of the competitive commercial activities of some agencies are exempt. I understand that and were that Commission in Part II, I would not raise the matter. But it seems rather odd that it should be in Part I. I refer also to the Aboriginal Land Councils and Land Trusts. No doubt some of those organisations would have commercial activities. Their documents in relation to those activities possibly ought to be exempt. But I am sure that they are engaged in many activities which do not require exemption and which in no sense involve the kinds of documents which the organisations themselves would expect to have classified or to be forbidden from public gaze. Mr Barry Jones-The ABC is the weirdest of them all.

Speaker: Mr HARRIS
Title: DISCHARGE OF TARIFF PROPOSALS
text: The Australian Broadcasting Commission is in Part II, not Part I, and it is exempt only in relation to its program material. I must confess that I am not entirely sure what that covers, although I believe it may include its own commercial or competitive activities. No doubt it has contractual relationships with a variety of ganisations and it may ev\!n have some copyright arran words mean, I dQ not complain about them. Nonetheless it seems to me that there are in the Schedules organisadonswhich are overly protected. I hope that the experiences ,of the first years of freedom of information legislation will demonstrate that there is no need to fear its operation. I hope that certain agencies of the Commonwealth Government will appreciate that there is no need to be totally exempt. I hope that when the review that the Attorney-General has promised for three years hence takes place, many of those agencies will at least be moved to Part II of the Schedule and that possibly some in Part II will be moved out. Otherwise, I support the Bill. Debate (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) adjourned.

text: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m. APPROPRIATION BILL (No.1) 1981-82 Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation for proposed expenditure annol,lnced. Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time. "Second Re!l!iing (Budget Speech)

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: DISCHARGE OF TARIFF PROPOSALS
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time, In doing so, ! presentthe Budget for 1981 -82. 1980-81 IN RETROSPECT 1980-81 was a year of solid growth and achievement for the Australian economy. It was a year in which the benefits of this Government's economic policies not only became more apparent, but were widely enjoyed by the Australian people. Nothing illustrates this more than the fact that real wages rose by over 4 per cent in 1980-81-a gain that was shared by 140000 extra people in employment. It was a year in which the fight against inflation was seen more clearly than ever before, not as an end in itself, but as a means of achieving greater investment, more jobs and higher living standards for all Australians. ' I say these things fully recognising that for those affected by the recent drought it was a year of adversity and, in many cases, real hardship, Economic success was achieved across a broad front. Production, employment, investment and conor- sumer demal1d were not only stronger than a year earlier, but greater than thought likely at the time of the last Budget. Australia's international reputation as a strong, reliable country in which to invest, was further enhanced. Among the economic indicators, the area of greatest strength was undoubtedly business investment, which contributes so much to activity and employment and hence to rising living standards. Even last year's optimistic Budget forecast of strong growth in this area clearly under-estimated the upsurge then in prospect. During 1980-81, private business fixed investment grew by more than 20 per cent in real terms-the largest such growth for 30 years. There could be no clearer proof of the extent to which confidence in the economic future of this country has returned. Although the mining sector made a hefty contribution towards this investment growth, strong increases were recorded in manufacturing and other sectors. Private dwelling investment continued to grow firmly, with a real increase of about 11 per cent. There was also a strong lift in personal consumption expenditure of about 3* per cent in real terms. Over the year to June 1981, Australia's inflation rate as measured by the Consumer Price Index was 8.8 per cent-almost 2 per cent below the rate a year earlier. This outcome-again better than had been forecast in last year's Budget-was aided by a lower rate of increase in import prices flowing in part from the strong appreciation of the Australian dollar. Although the margin narrowed, Australia's inflation rate remained below the average of OECD countries. Business profits grew strongly last year but further growth, so vital to continued investment and employment, is now being threatened by rising wage pressures. Overall, gross domestic product increased by almost 3 per cent in 1980-81, with growth of 4 per cent in the non-farm sector being offset by the fall in farm product associated with the drought. The sharp rise in non-farm activity was reflected in a strong rise in total employment, which increased by 2.6 pet cent. This was enough to reduce overall unemployment to its lowest level for four years, well beyond our original expectations. This brief summary of the Australian economy over the past year presents a picture of considerable success and progress. It contrasts sharply with the general experience of other OECD countries where, in aggregate, there has been higher inflation and unemployment and slower growth. I would, however, be less than frank if I did not also point to some areas of concern to the Government and to certain challenges which, if not effectively tackled by this Budget and policies more generally, could undermine the progress and success to which I have referred. If a response to those challenges is put off to another day, they will be infinitely harder to resolve, the process of resolution more painful and the damage to our economic recovery' all the greater. In my Budget Speech a year ago, I spoke of the threat then posed by excessive wage demands and industrial disputes. Regrettably, the past year-and particularly the past few months-has seen the pressure for higher wages intensify. If unchecked, this will not only lead to higher inflation but reverse the falling trend in unemployment and put at risk both investment and employment growth. It would be grossly unfair if excessive wage demands from those in employment wereo.ow to damage the prospects for further job creation just when we have begun to see real gains being made in reducing unemployment. It is important that the abandonment of the wage indexation principles not be seen as having left a vacuum in this area. In, recent days Commonwealth and State Governments, as well as the ACTU and National Employers, have all pointed to the continued existence of workable conciliation and arbitration processes-which in some respects ate more flextheir ible than the indexation arrangements-to settle wage claims. It is essential that all parties cooperate to make these processes work effectively. Such an outcome would help to moderate excessive wage claims. NA No Government likes to see interest rates go up. This Government is acutely conscious of the effects of rising interest rates on all borrowers, especially home-buyers. We therefore regret the necessity for the further increases announced last week. It is important for all of us to understand why interest rates have increased and what needs to be done to reverse this trend. Interest rates have risen because the total demand for money in the community has exceeded its availability. In such circumstances interest rate rises are unavoidable unless the Government were prepared to print as much money as was demanded. This it will not do because of the inflationary consequences. -, It f-llows that if interest rates are to be brought down the growth in the total d,emand for money must be reduced. This demand comes from a number of sources, including businesses and 'prospective hom--buyers. There are also demands from governments at all levels to finance their current activities and to refinance earlier deficits. In recent years government borrowing demands have been reduced, due entirely to reductions in the Commonwealth Budget deficit. However, with strong private sector demand, this fall has not been sufficient to prevent increase in the total demand for funds. As a consequence, there has been upward pressure on interest rates. If this pressure is to be eased in a way that not damage private sector activity or add to inflation-outcomes that would reduce job opportunities and retard economic growth-it is imperative that the borrowing demands of all levels of government be further reduced. The need for such action led to the Loan Council decisions in June to cut by about 4 per cent in real terms the total Commonwealth and State semi-government borrowing programs. Clearly, however, this Budget must make a further and substantial contribution towards reducing government borrowing demands if the upward pressure on interest rates is to be eased and indeed reversed. I can think of no cause more important to Australian families at present. We have therefore decided that this year we must go as far as possible towards eliminating the Commonwealth's Budget deficit. THE BUDGET OUTCOME FOR 1980-81 Last year's Budget generated the first domestic surplus since 1973-74; in the outcome, both it and the overall deficit were about $400 million better than had been expected. Outlays were within 1 per cent of the Budget estimate. Receipts, however, were 2 per cent-$683 million-greater than estimated, mainly reflecting larger than expected income tax collections from both individuals and companies. Receipts from the crude oil levy were $35 million less than estimated, with the effects of industrial disputes on production from Bass Strait more than offsetting the higher import parity price from I January 1981. For two years in a row now, large reductions in the Commonwealth Budget deficit-$1444 million in 1979-80 and $906 million in 1980-81-have been accompanied by strong growth in private sector economic activity. NA In putting together this year's Budget the Government had to ensure that it would meet a possible resurgence of inflation head on. A less firm Budget, while easier to prepare, would carry wof inflation, thereby undermining the prospects for sustained economic growth in a significant the years ahead. In particular, the uncertainty and loss of international competitiveness that would result from a new inflationary spiral would deter the production and investment essential to the creation does of additional jobs and higher real incomes. We have therefore opted for a Budget which gives priority to containing and reducing inflation and sustaining private sector growth. It is a Budget which reduces the overall deficit by almost $1000 million. This decisive move towards overall balance symbolises the Government's determination to play safe with the gains we have already made.
