NA As the figures I have just quoted show, this Budget represents a decisive response, in the area of fiscal policy, to mounting wage and cost pressures. By restraining the growth in total outlaysÂ· the Budget will curb public sector demands on real resources at a time when those resources are being keenly sought by expanding businesses in the private sector. It will also significantly reduce the total public sector requirement for loanable funds in 1981-82 at a time when the corporate sector is likely to be seeking substantially larger borrowings to help finance its investment program. This wi\l help to ease the pressures which, otherwise, 'that increase in private borrowings would produce. For a variety of reasons monetary conditions last year were more accommodating than had been intended; one illustration of this is that M3 increased by 12.7 per cent during the course of 1980-81 compared with the Budget projection of about 9 to II per cent. While there are many unpredictable influences on the money supply-including external developments in particular-it is fundamental to winding back inflation that growth in the monetary aggregates also be wound back. In particular, we are determined not to allow the money supply to expand so as to accommodate a new round of excessive wageincreases. In these circumstances, it is clearly desirable that the rate of growth of the money supply be reduced. The Government will therefore be seeking to restrain growth in the monetary aggregates to a degree consistent with growth in M3 of 10 to 11 per cent over the course of 1981-82. The sharply reduced Commonwealth B-dget deficit will facilitate this task. but an appropriate balance, of domestic and external policies will also be required. The increases in tap stock yields announc!'!d after last, week's Loan Council meeting, taken together with this Budget, will make a major contribution towards reducing pressures on interest rates, settling capital markets arid restraining monetary growth. As in recent years, arrangements will be made for the forthcoming wheat harvest to be financed in a manner consistent with monetary objectives. This tightening of fiscal and monetary policies is designed to prevent an acceleration in the underlying rate of inflation in 1981-82. Avoiding that acceleration is essential to restoring the conditions for a downward movement in 1982-83 and later years. It is to be hoped that current developments in the wages area will lead to more flexible and more , orderly wage determination processes which pay proper regard to the economy's capacity to bear wage increases. I have already referred to the responsibilities on all parties in this regard. Given developments to date, hqwever, it appears that average weekly earnings in 1981-82 could rise by about 13t per cent. This would be much the same as in 1980-81, when the rise in earnings was enlarged by the flow through of the so-called 'work-value' round of wage increases which began in 1978. On that basis, the forecast rise in the Consumer Price Index in 1981-82 as a whole is about 10f per cent. Leaving aside the effects of the revenue measures mentioned in the Budget and the previously announced changes in health care ar' rangements, the rise would be a little under 9+ per cent-an underlying rate of inflation much the same as that recorded in 1980-81. The tighter policy framework which is now essential for containing inflationary pressures does of course carry some implications in the short-term for activity and employment. Nevertheless, the non-farm sector of the economy should continue to grow strongly in 1981-82. Business fixed investment, in particular, seems certain to grow rapidly again this year. The rate of that expansion-especially in the building and construction sector-will depend importantly on the availability of materials and skilled labour, including the extent to which supplies of both can be augmented from overseas. Given continued strong growth in real household incomes, personal consumption expenother diture could rise a little faster in 1981-82perhaps by around 3+ per cent. Private dwelling investment, however, is likely to decline somewhat in 1981-82 after rapid increases in each of the past two years. This will in part reflect a reduction in investment and speculative activity. The Government continues to attach a high priority to maintaining a steady flow of private housing finance. The availability of such finance will be affected, of course, by the relative competitiveness of interest rates offered and hence the rates charged by housing finance institutions. As this Budget demonstrates, the Government has made major efforts to reduce public sector pressures on capital markets in the interests of limiting the competitive pressures on housing finance and interest rates. On present indications gross non-farm product could grow by between 3 and 3+ per cent this year-below the 4 per cent rate estimated for 1980-81, but higher than the average rate of about 2t per cent in the second half of the 1970s. With farm production expected to recover in 1981-82, gross domestic product could rise by more than 3+ per cent thjs year, compared with about 3 per cent last year. This outlook is considered to be consistent with employment growth of about 2 per cent in 1981-82. This would be below the increases of about 2t per cent recorded in each of the past two years but would still represent strong growth in employment, particularly by, standards in o,ther industrialised ecoI;lomies today. A further strong increase in imports is likely in 1981-82 but any recovery in the level of exports will be limited by the continued sluggishness in world trade-a fact which u,nderlines the paramount need for Australia not to throwaway the international competitiveness so hard won over recent years. Taken together with the prospect for invisibles; this means that the current account deficit may widen further in 1981-82 to around 4t per cent of GDP. Though the outlook for the balance of payments is as always subject to many uncertainties, it seems reasonable to expect this current account deficit to be covered by private capital inflowprovided that, as we are determined they shall be, wage demands and inflation are successfully contained. In those circumstances a surplus on private sector foreign exchange transactions of a similar order of magnitude to the $2800m recorded last year could occur. It is vital to the nation's no acceleration in the rate of inflation in 1981-82. Such an outcome would have most adverse consequences for confidence-both here and abroad-in Australia's future and for the competitiveness of our industr'ies. This is especially so given that most of the major industrialised countries, led by the United States, are now bent on firm anti-inflation policies. ' Australia has been doing better than many of these countries in containing inflationary pressures in recent years, Our aim is to keep it that way. This Budget is an essential part bf the Government's strategy for containing wage and price inflation. It will also help in a major way to ease pressures on interest rates. The Budget is being supported-and will continue to be supported-by equally decisive action in monetary and other policy areas. Such action is necessary if we are not only to preserve the hard won gains of the past but also if we are to exploit the potential for even greater gains in the years ahead from the large investments now under way, particularly in resource projects. The Budget will also help to maintain further solid growth in private sector activity and to provide more jobs for Australians. text: lmove: That the Bill be now read a second time. This Bill seeks appropriation of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1981-82 totalling $1,333.3m. NA STAMP DUTY AMENDMENT BILL 1981 Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY
text: Ryan-Minister for Business 'Second Reading and Consumer Affairs) (9.6)-I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. This Bill is the first of three Bills needed to give effect to the proposal announced in the Budget Speech by the Treasurer (MrHoward) earlier tonight to increase the rates of stamp duty and similar tax payable in respect of certain instruments and transactions connected with the Australian Capital Territory, including the Jervis Bay territory. By way of background, I mention that stamp duty was introduced in 1969 on a range of instruments and transactions in the Australian Capital Territory. At that time, the rates of duty were set at levels comparable with rates imposed by the States on similar instruments and transactions. In the intervening years the rates of duty applying to the majority of instruments and transactions dutiable in the Territory have fallen significantly behind those imposed by the States. The Government believes that there is no justification for maintaining this advantage for residents of the Australian Capital Territory over residents of the various States. For this reason, and taking into account also the marked growth of Canberra both as a city and as a centre of business, the GovernBUDGET 1981-82 ment has decided to take steps that ensure that residents of the Territory bear stamp duties comparable with those levied on residents of the States. This Bill and the Bills that follow give effect to this decision. I refer now to the various instruments that are to be subject to an increased rate of duty. Cheques drawn or made on a banker at a branch of the banker in the Territory, and other bills of exchange or promissory notes drawn or paid in the Territory, are the first category. The present the Northern Territory and rate of stamp duty on this category of instrument is 5c. The rate proposed by this Bill is 10c per instrument. The new rate will apply in respect of cheques drawn on or after 19 August 1981 and to any other bill of exchange or promissory note that has not been duly stamped by reason of having been drawn or paid before 19 August 1981. Transitional arrangements included in the Bill will, however, enable bank customers to continue to draw cheques on forms supplied to them before 19 August 1981 without incurring the higher duty. It is also proposed that conveyances of freehold land in the Territory and agreements for the granting, transfer orassignment of leases of land in the Territory executed on or after 19 August 1981 will be subject to increased rates of duty. The increase will not apply in respect of conveyancing transactions for which an agreement for transfer had been executed by the pa,rties before 19 August 1981. For a transfer of freehold land, the present rate of duty is at the fiat rate of $1 for each $100, or part thereof, of the value of the interest transferred. This basis of duty also applies in respect of a transfer of a crown lease granted for more than five years. For other transfers of leases, including Crown leases granted for periods of five years or less, the existing rate of duty same as 1I have just mentioned, but it is imposed on the value of the' consideration given by the transferee. The remaining dutiable transaction dealt with by the Bill is the grant of a lease other than by the Commonwealth. On the granting of such a lease, duty is presently payable at the general rate 1I have mentioned but is applied to the value of the consideration given by the lessee otherwise than by way of rent. For consideration given in the form of rent, duty is imposed at the rate of 30c for each $100, or part thereof, on the total rent payable for the specified period for which the lease is granted. It is proposed that the general rate of stamp duty in respect of all of these classes of instruments be increased, as follows: For every $100, or part thereof, of the freehold value or lease premium the rate is to be $1.25 for amounts up to $14,000; $1.50 between $14,001 and $30,000; $1.75 between $30,001 and $50,000; $2 between $50,001 and $100,000; $2.25 between $100,001 and $250,000; and $2.50 for amounts in excess of $250,000. It is also proposed that the duty payable in respect of the rental component of a lease be increased from 30c to 35c per $100 or part thereof. A memorandum containing more detailed explanations of the technical aspects of this Bill and the other two Bills to which 1I have referred is being circulated to honourable members. 1 mention that legislation to introduce a Territory stamp duty on new and transferred vehicle registrations and on life insurance policies will be brought before Parliament later in the sittings. 1 commend the present Bill to the House. SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act to alter the sales tax classification of certain goods. I referred to this Act when speaking a moment ago about rates of sales tax and indicated that the exemptions and classifications Act not only classifies particular goods as exempt from sales tax but also places other goods in one or other of the tax rate categories. The present Bill is primarily concerned with the alteration of those sales tax classifications. In all, there are some 36 substantial changes. In a sales tax system that has exemptions and a number of rate categories it is inevitable that at the border line between one category and another there will be anomalies, real or apparent. There has in fact been no general review of the sales tax classification of goods for many years and a review that has been carried out has brought to the Government's attention a number of anomalies and inconsistencies which we think should be remedied. In carrying out the review we have given attention to representations that have been made to the Government by honourable members and other interested people. The sales tax system operates according to a number of principles. In our review, we have endeavoured to work within these. We have been concerned to remove anomalies in classifications that give some goods a competitive advantage over other products and to achieve a greater measure of uniformity in classification. We have necessarily had to keep an eye on the revenue consequences of the possible solutions that have come up for consideration. We have found in our review that certain exemption provisions have not kept pace with technological changes. Decisions of the courts and administrative experience have highlighted weaknesses in the law that allow exemptions beyond what waswhen the law was first framed, or that result in an unacceptable lack of clarity in the law. Some exemption items have become redundant due to changes in other laws, such as those relating to customs duties and laws covering the manufacture of motor vehicles. A riumber of amendments resulting from the review will bring into the taxable field goods which, for technical reasons only, have had to be accepted as exempt, although the 1981 exemption does not fit in with the general policy of the tax. Other amendments will, for consistency's sake, move goods into a higher tax bracket. However, it is not all a one way street and in some Second Reading instances anomalies and inconsistencies are being removed by exempting goods that are at present taxable. Speaking in more detail, one of the important changes relates to the treatment of containers for use in marketing soft drinks. At present, nonreturnable bottles used in marketing taxable soft drinks are exempt from sales tax, while cans used for the same purpose are taxable. Manufacturers of cans have urged the Government to remedy this inconsistent treatment. We propose to correct it by removing the exemption for non-returnable bottles and containers used in marketing soft drinks. Returnable bottles will remain exempt. Photographic materials and products are generally taxable at 27+ per cent, or 30 per cent as they will be from tonight. However, the particular item, which was intended to cover all photographic materials, does not catch instant-type film packs which have become popular in recent times. These packs compete with conventional films and it is appropriate that they be taxed on the same basis. Similarly, photographic cameras and equipment have been taxable at 27+ per cent, while projectors and other viewing equipment have been taxable at 15 per cent. Both will now attract tax at the new rate of 30 per cent. Projection equipment of the kind used for commercial purposes, such as in theatres, will remain taxable at the lower rate. Further alterations relate to the unusual position of cathode \ray tubes for television sets and motor vehicle seat belts. A general principle of the sales tax law is that goods are classified according to their commercial indentity, and not on the basis of the component parts of which they are comprised. Television receivers, of which the picture tubes form a major part, and motor vehicles, in which seat belts are fitted, are taxable as such. However, for reasons relevant at the time but no longer applicable, provisions were' introduced into the law some years ago to exempt cathode ray tubes and motor vehicle seat belts from sales tax, even where they form an integral part of taxable goods. The reasons for this special treatment having disappeared, it is proposed to repeal the relevant exemption provisions. This will result in these goods being taxed according to the identity of the product of which they form part, or in their own right when sold separately. Foodstuffs for human consumption, but not including confectionery, are exempt from tax. Due to deficiencies in the law, the exemptions relating to foodstuffs have in some instances not operated as intended. They were never intended to exempt manufactured pet food, but exemption for this has had to be conceded under the present law. It is proposed to restrict the foodstuffs exemption to goods for human consumption, with the result that manufactured pet food will again become taxable. Food for livestock will remain exempt under other provisions. A similar problem has arisen with certain chocolate-coated confectionery. As a general rule, confectionery is taxable. However, some confectionery lines have gained exemption on the basis that they are biscuits which are exempt under the general foodstuffs exemption. These lines compete directly with others of the same basic type and are sold as confectionery. They are now to be taxed as such. Some industry-related exemptions in the law which are couched in wide terms do not specifically exclude road vehicles and this has led to some industries being able to obtain vehicles free of tax, while vehicles for use in other industries remain taxable. A particular problem has occurred in connection with road vehicles used for bulk handling of grain. Relevant exemptions are to be amended to exclude road vehicles, so as to place industry use of vehicles on a more equitable footing and to prevent continuation of abuses that have occurred. Consistent with the overall philosophy of the sales tax law in relation to motor vehicles, it is proposed to tax oil, greases and other lubricants used for motor vehicles. These goods are at present exempt whereas motor fuels are subject to excise. These comments. outline the more important alterations to sales tax classifications that will result in increases in revenue. There are others, but I think what I have said sufficiently illustrates the kind of adjustments that are to be effected by the Bill. The other alterations will result in the withdrawal of minor exemptions and the restriction of certain business exemptions to restore them to their original intention. I think that I need not go into all of them in this introductory speech. They are fully explained in the explanatory memorandum that is being circulated to honourable members. There is one further point, however, that I should mention. It is a feature of the sales tax law that aids to manufacture-goods used in manufacturing processes-are exempt from the tax. The Bill makes a number of amendments to the definition of aids to manufacture to clarify its meaning and to remove weaknesses. I indicated earlier that there are measures in the Bill that will reduce sales tax revenue and they are also covered in the explanatory memorandum. There are three I would like to make some comment about at this stage. The first relates to log forwarders for use in timber-getting. The expansion of logging of softwood forests has led to the development of specialised equipment called log forwarders to haul the felled logs from the felling point in the forest to road-side pick-up points. These vehicles perform the saine function as tractors, which are exempt. It is proposed, in the interests of equity and consistency, to provide an exemption for log forwarders also. I am sure the timber industry will welcome the Government's decision, both because it recognises technological advances in the industry and because log forwarders give better protection to forests than less sophisticated equipment does. The Government has also decided to exempt protective clothing of a kind used for sport or recreation, such as helmets, guards, gloves and mittens. Clothing in general, including sporting clothing such as football jumpers, cricket trousers and swim wear are already exempt. The protective headgear, pads, gloves and mittens are worn primarily to protect participants from injury and it is proposed to bring these goods into line with clothing in general. Exemption is also being proposed for compressed natural gas. This is consistent with the Government's energy policy. Natural gas supplied through a reticulation system is already exempt. The net result of the changes will be an increase in revenue estimated at $142m in a full year and $ 107m in 1981-82. It is customary for sales tax changes to come into operation on the day following the introduction of the amending Bill and the Bill therefore provides that the amendments are to be effective from tomorrow, 19 August 1981. Other sales tax changes that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced in his Budget Speech-those that involve tax of 2t per cent on a number of goods now exempt from sales tax-will be the subject of legislation to be brought in later in the sittings. That legislation will not come into operation until 1 January 1982. I commend this Bill to the House. Debate (on the motion by Mr Dawkins) adjourned. Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS
text: I move: That the Bills be now read a second time. These Bills will give effect to the proposal the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced in the Budget Speech to increase the various rates of sales tax by 2t percentage points. The Bills will increase the respective rates from 2t per cent to 5 per cent, from 15 per cent to 17t and from 27t per cent to 30 per cent. The nine amending Bills are necessary because sales tax is imposed by nine separate Acts in order to meet the constitutional requirement that an Act imposing taxation shall deal with only one subject of taxation. Increased rates of tax are proposed for all goods other than those covered by the first Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, and which are thereby made exempt from sales tax. The second Schedule to that Act identifies the goods that are to be taxed at the top rate, now to be 30 per cent. Goods embraced by the second Schedule include radio and television receivers, record players, cameras, films and photographs, watches, jewellery, cosmetics, fountain pens, certain goods made of precious metals andÂ· furs. Goods in the third Schedule to the exemptions and classifications Act at present attract a rate of 2t per cent, which is now to be increased to 5 per cent. This covers household furniture, appliances such as refrigerators, washing machines and a range of household goods. Motor cars and commercial motor vehicles are in the fourth and fifth Schedules to the exemptions and classifications Act and they, together with goods not coming within the terms of any schedule to that Act, are at present taxed at 15 per cent. It is proposed that they be taxed in future at 17t per cent. Other goods also now to be taxed at 17t percent include boats, confectionery, stationery, computers, soft drinks, potable spirits and imported wines and beers. It is customary for changes in the rates of sales tax to take effect on the day following the introduction of amending Bills and these Bills, when enacted, will come into operation tomorrow, 19 August 1981. The sales tax is basically a tax on sales at the wholesale level and, in the ordinary case of sales by a wholesaler to a retailer, the increased rates of tax will accordingly apply to sales made after today. As usual, an explanatory memorandum covering technical aspects of the Bills and provid(Nos 1 to 9) 1981 ing, on this occasion, a detailed listing of the goods affected by these measures is being made available to honourable members. I commend the Bills to the House. Second Readings pebate (on motion by Mr Dawkins) adjourned. NA

The effects of the Proposals are to impose a duty of $1 per tonne on coal that was previously exempt from export duty, that is, coal that: The Collector of Customs is satisfied the crueible swelling number of which is not greater than 3; or the Collector of Customs is satisfied, if subjected to proximate analysis, on an air dried basis, would be classified as coal having an ash content greater than 12 per cent. NA FEES AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1981 Bill presented by Mr Sinclair, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The main purposes for imposing a fee on companies licensed to earn income from broadcasting are to cover the cost of industry regulation, and to contribute to overall Commonwealth revenue requirements. The Government is, however, concerned that due notice is taken in this process of the ability of the industry to pay. It has, therefore, canvassed a number of alternatives for a new formula for calculating radio and television licence fees which would take into account the projected profitability of broadcasters in all areas. Changes contained in the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill and its counterpart, the Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill, are designed to give a measure of relief to commercial licensees whose stations' gross earnings were less than about $2tm in 1980-81. For some 120 of the 130 radio stations, licence fees would be reduced. For stations whose operating costs would be increased by these proposed changes, there would be some offsetting income tax effect. The formula for calculating radio station licence fees proposed in this Bill removes the $200 lump sum component of the annual fee,and varies the percentage of a stations' gross earnings which is payable as the licence fee. For stations with low gross earnings, the percentage payable as the licence fee is reduced, and for other stations the percentage payable is increased. The Bill also proposes that the fee payable on the grant of a commercial radio licence would be increased from $200 to $500. The new measures in this Bill, and the Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill, effective from 1 September 1981, are expected to yield the Commonwealth an extra $5m in revenue from licence fees in this financial year. I commend this Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) adjourned. NA AMENDMENT BILL 1981 Bill presented by Mr Sinclair, and read a first time. .

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: DEPARTURE TAX COLLECTION
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. This Bill is a machinery Bill. It is designed amend the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952 which prescribes the charges payable in respect the use by aircraft of aerodromes, air route and airway facilities, meteorological services search and rescue services maintained, operated or provided by the Commonwealth. The purpose of the Bill is to vary the rates of air navigation charges-ANCs-payable for aircraft operating in all sectors of the aviation industry. It is proposed that the variations should be effective from 1 October 1981. The variations proposed in the rate of ANCs are to reduce the rates applicable to the interBoth national sector by 5 per cent; to increase the rates applicable to the domestic airline sector by 12t per cent; to increase the rates applicable to the gional airline sector by 25 per cent; and to crease the rates applicable to the general aviation sectors by 20 per cent. If these proposals are ceptable to the Parliament, it is estimated revenue to be earned by the Commonwealth ANCs in 1981-82 will, together with payments made in that year for 1980-81 operations, total $115.76m. This compares with the $95.89m accord received from ANCs in 1980-81. Further, levels _of increase proposed for the domestic air1981-82. lines should have a minimal effect on air fares as they should increase airline costs by about one per cent for regional airlines and about 0.5 per cent for domestic trunk airlines. The impact on total costs faced by general aviation operators is also expected to be minimal. Honourable m-embers will be aware that since 1961 the Government has had a policy for the eventual full recovery of the costs properly attributable to the air transport industry from providing and maintaining the aviation infrastructure. Full recovery of attributable costs was first achieved in 1975-76 in respect of the international sector. While this sector has continued to be fully recovered the rates of ANCs for international operations have not been varied since 1 December 1976. Further, in the 1980-81 Budget, the Government announced that over recovery in this area should be credited to the cost recovery program and appiied to the development of the aviation infrastructure. The Government has decided that there should be a reduction of 5 per cent in the rate of ANCs for international operators effective from I October 1981. While there Second Reading will be over recovery in this sector, the Government re-affirms its 1980-81 decision on the treatment to be afforded over recovery from this sector of the industry. It should be noted also that the Australian to charges for international operations compare more than favourably with those imposed overof seas when the comparison is made on the same . basis. Australia, unlike most overseas countries, and imposes a composite fee which covers landing fees, parking fees, terminal air traffic control and en-route aids and services, et cetera. Overseas, these elements are often the subject of separate charges which can be raised by different authorities, and in some cases they may vary accordingly. These charges, however, were to be reviewed in the light of the study of the general aviation sector. As honourable members will know, the Government has not accepted the cost recovery recommendations of the general aviation study, although the rate of charges will continue to be reviewed annually.
